ingredients: 3 cups finely chopped cabbage , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 2 green chilies, chopped , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2-3 dry red chilies , 1 sprig curry leaves , 2 tablespoons coconut oil , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste.
instruction: Heat coconut oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and allow them to splutter. Add cumin seeds, dry red chilies, and curry leaves. Sauté for a few seconds until fragrant. Add chopped cabbage, green chilies, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well. Cover and cook for 8-10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the cabbage is tender. Once the cabbage is cooked, add grated coconut and mix well. Cook for another 2-3 minutes. Remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Cashew & Drumstick Avial
description: Savor the harmonious blend of flavors in this delectable Cashew & Drumstick Avial. Tender drumstick pieces and creamy cashew nuts come together in a coconut-based gravy, infused with the subtle heat of green chilies and aromatic curry leaves. This South Indian delicacy, prepared with a hint of turmeric and mustard seeds, offers a delightful culinary experience that pairs perfectly with steamed rice or as a side dish. Enjoy a taste of tradition with this wholesome and nutritious dish, brimming with regional flavors and culinary heritage.
ingredients: 1 cup cashew nuts , 2-3 drumsticks, cut into 2-inch pieces , 1 cup grated coconut , 2 green chilies, chopped , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon coconut oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 2-3 dried red chilies , A few curry leaves.
instruction: In a pot, boil the drumstick pieces with a pinch of turmeric powder and salt until they are tender. Drain and set aside. In a blender, grind the grated coconut and green chilies to a coarse paste without adding water. Heat coconut oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Then add dried red chilies and curry leaves. Add the boiled drumstick pieces and cashew nuts to the pan. Mix well. Add the ground coconut paste, turmeric powder, and salt. Stir everything together. Cook for 5-7 minutes on low heat until the flavors blend well and the mixture thickens slightly. Remove from heat and serve hot with rice or as a side dish.

name: Chattipathiri
description: A savory delight hailing from the Malabar region of Kerala, Chattipathiri is a layered pastry dish that combines thin crepes and spiced chicken omelettes. Each layer is infused with a medley of flavors, from the warmth of garam masala to the subtle kick of green chilies. Topped with a sprinkling of chopped nuts, this dish offers a delightful balance of textures and tastes, making it a perfect choice for a hearty meal or festive occasion.
ingredients: For Crepes: 1 cup all-purpose flour , 2 eggs , 1 ½ cups milk , Salt, to taste , For Filling: 300g boneless chicken, cooked and shredded , 4 eggs , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 2 tablespoons chopped coriander leaves , ½ teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon garam masala , Salt, to taste , Other: Ghee or butter, for frying , Chopped nuts (cashews, almonds), for garnish.
instruction: Prepare Crepes: In a mixing bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, eggs, milk, and salt until smooth. Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and lightly grease it with ghee or butter. Pour a ladleful of the batter onto the pan and spread it thinly to form a crepe. Cook until the bottom is golden brown, then flip and cook the other side. Repeat with the remaining batter to make crepes. Set aside. Prepare Filling: In a bowl, beat the eggs and add cooked shredded chicken, chopped onion, green chilies, coriander leaves, turmeric powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well. Heat a non-stick pan and pour a ladleful of the egg-chicken mixture onto it. Spread it evenly to form a thin omelette. Cook until set, then flip and cook the other side. Repeat with the remaining mixture to make thin omelettes. Set aside. Assemble Chattipathiri: Preheat the oven to 180°C (350°F). Take a baking dish and lightly grease it with ghee or butter. Place a crepe at the bottom of the baking dish. Top it with a thin omelette. Repeat the layers, alternating between crepes and omelettes, until all the crepes and omelettes are used. Finish with a layer of crepe on top. Brush the top layer with ghee or butter. Sprinkle chopped nuts over the top layer for garnish. Bake: Cover the baking dish with aluminum foil and bake in the preheated oven for about 20-25 minutes, or until the Chattipathiri is heated through and the top is golden brown. Serve: Remove from the oven and let it cool for a few minutes. Cut into slices and serve warm. Enjoy the delicious layers of flavor!

name: Cherupayar Thoran
description: A traditional South Indian dish made with green gram (cherupayar), this nutritious and flavorful recipe is a delightful addition to any meal. Cooked with onions, green chilies, and a hint of coconut, Cherupayar Thoran offers a perfect balance of textures and tastes. Enjoy it as a side dish with rice or roti for a wholesome and satisfying dining experience.
ingredients: 1 cup green gram (cherupayar), soaked overnight , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2-3 green chilies, chopped , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 2-3 dry red chilies , A few curry leaves , 2 tablespoons grated coconut , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon coconut oil.
instruction: Drain the soaked green gram and rinse it thoroughly. Set aside. Heat coconut oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter. Add dry red chilies and curry leaves to the pan. Saute for a few seconds. Add chopped onions and green chilies to the pan. Saute until the onions turn translucent. Add the soaked green gram to the pan along with turmeric powder and salt. Mix well. Cover and cook the mixture on low heat until the green gram is tender, stirring occasionally. Once the green gram is cooked, add grated coconut to the pan and mix everything well. Cook for another 2-3 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend together. Remove from heat and transfer the Cherupayar Thoran to a serving dish. Serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Chiratta Puttu
description: A traditional Kerala delicacy, Chiratta Puttu is a steamed cylindrical rice cake layered with grated coconut. Made by alternating layers of rice flour mixture and coconut in a chiratta puttu kutti (cylindrical puttu mould), it's steamed until cooked to perfection.
ingredients: 2 cups rice flour , 1 cup grated coconut , Salt to taste , Water as needed.
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine rice flour, grated coconut, and salt. Mix well. Gradually add water and knead the mixture until it reaches a crumbly texture. Take a chiratta puttu kutti (cylindrical puttu mould) and fill the bottom with grated coconut. Add a layer of the prepared rice flour mixture followed by another layer of grated coconut. Repeat until the mould is filled. Steam the filled mould for about 10-15 minutes until the puttu is cooked. Once cooked, gently push the puttu out of the mould and serve hot with cheru payar or banana.

name: Erissery
description: Erissery is a classic Kerala dish that combines the subtle sweetness of pumpkin and yam with the earthy flavor of black-eyed peas, all simmered in a creamy coconut gravy. This traditional recipe is a delightful medley of textures and tastes, making it a favorite choice for festive occasions and everyday meals alike. With its aromatic spices and wholesome ingredients, Erissery captures the essence of South Indian cuisine and promises a satisfying culinary experience for all.
ingredients: 1 cup pumpkin, diced , 1/2 cup yam, diced , 1/4 cup black-eyed peas (vanpayar), soaked overnight , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 2-3 green chilies , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , For Tempering: 1 tablespoon coconut oil , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 2-3 dry red chilies , A few curry leaves.
instruction: Pressure cook the soaked black-eyed peas with a little salt until they are soft. Drain and set aside. In a separate pot, cook the diced pumpkin and yam with turmeric powder, green chilies, and salt until they are tender. Mash them slightly. Grind the grated coconut with a little water to a smooth paste. Add the cooked black-eyed peas to the mashed pumpkin and yam mixture. Stir in the ground coconut paste and mix well. Adjust the salt if needed. Let it simmer for a few minutes until the flavors blend together. In a small pan, heat coconut oil for tempering. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add dry red chilies and curry leaves. Saute for a few seconds. Pour the tempering over the erissery and mix well. Serve hot with steamed rice or Kerala parotta.

name: Neichoru
description: Neichoru, a traditional South Indian delicacy, is a fragrant and flavorful dish known for its simplicity and rich taste. Made with fragrant Basmati rice cooked in ghee (clarified butter) and infused with aromatic spices like cloves, cardamom, cinnamon, and bay leaf, this dish is a perfect accompaniment to any curry or side dish. With a preparation time of just 10 minutes and cooking time of 20 minutes, Neichoru is a quick and easy recipe suitable for any occasion. Each serving of this delightful dish provides approximately 300 calories, making it a satisfying and wholesome addition to any meal.
ingredients: 2 cups Basmati rice , 4 cups water , 1/4 cup ghee (clarified butter) , 1 onion, thinly sliced , 2-3 cloves , 2-3 cardamom pods , 1 cinnamon stick , 1 bay leaf , Salt to taste.
instruction: Rinse the Basmati rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain and set aside. In a large pot, heat the ghee over medium heat. Add the sliced onions and sauté until golden brown. Add the cloves, cardamom pods, cinnamon stick, and bay leaf to the pot. Sauté for another minute until fragrant. Add the drained rice to the pot and sauté for 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally. Pour in the water and add salt to taste. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until the rice is cooked through and all the water is absorbed. Once cooked, fluff the rice with a fork and remove from heat. Let it sit, covered, for 5 minutes before serving. Serve hot as a side dish with your favorite curry or accompaniment.

name: Gooseberry Pickle
description: This tangy and spicy Gooseberry Pickle is a delightful addition to any meal. Made with fresh gooseberries and aromatic spices like mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, and turmeric, this pickle bursts with flavor. It's easy to prepare and pairs perfectly with rice, roti, or any Indian meal. Enjoy the unique taste of this homemade pickle that will leave your taste buds craving for more!
ingredients: 500 grams fresh gooseberries (washed and dried) , 4 tablespoons mustard oil , 2 teaspoons mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon fenugreek seeds , 1 teaspoon fennel seeds , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 2 tablespoons red chili powder , 2 tablespoons salt , 2 tablespoons jaggery (optional, for sweetness) , 1 tablespoon lemon juice (optional).
instruction: Heat mustard oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, and fennel seeds. Saute for a minute until the seeds start to splutter. Add turmeric powder and red chili powder. Mix well and cook for another minute. Add the washed and dried gooseberries to the pan. Stir gently to coat the gooseberries with the spices. Cook the gooseberries on low heat for about 10-15 minutes until they soften slightly. Stir occasionally to prevent burning. Once the gooseberries are cooked, add salt and jaggery (if using). Mix well and cook for another 2-3 minutes. Turn off the heat and let the pickle cool down to room temperature. Once cooled, transfer the gooseberry pickle to a clean, dry glass jar. You can optionally add lemon juice for extra tanginess. Your Gooseberry Pickle is ready to be served! Enjoy it with your favorite meals.

name: Idiyappam
description: Idiyappam, a traditional South Indian delicacy, is a simple yet delicious steamed dish made from rice flour and hot water. The dough is extruded through a special press to form thin strands, which are then steamed until soft and fluffy. Idiyappam pairs perfectly with various curries, coconut milk, or even sugar, making it a versatile and satisfying meal option for breakfast or dinner.
ingredients: 2 cups rice flour , 1 ½ cups hot water , Salt to taste.
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, add rice flour and salt. Gradually pour hot water into the flour while stirring continuously with a spoon. Mix until the dough comes together and becomes smooth. It should be soft and pliable. Once the dough is ready, take a portion of it and fill an idiyappam maker (also known as a 'sev press' or 'sevai maker') with the dough. Heat a steamer with water. Place a muslin cloth or banana leaf over the steamer plate. Press the dough through the idiyappam maker onto the cloth or banana leaf in a circular motion to form thin strands. Repeat the process with the remaining dough until the steamer plate is filled with idiyappam strands. Steam the idiyappam for about 8-10 minutes or until they are cooked through and become firm. Once done, carefully remove the idiyappam from the steamer and transfer them to a serving plate. Serve hot with your favorite curry, coconut milk, or sugar.

name: Kaalan
description: Kaalan is a traditional Kerala dish made with a combination of yam, raw plantains, and ash gourd cooked in a coconut-yogurt gravy. This flavorful dish is seasoned with turmeric, cumin seeds, green chilies, and tempered with mustard seeds, dry red chilies, and curry leaves in coconut oil. It's a creamy and mildly spiced delicacy that pairs perfectly with steamed rice, offering a delightful culinary experience rooted in Kerala's rich culinary heritage.
ingredients: 1 cup of chopped yam (chena) , 1 cup of chopped raw plantains (ethakka) , 1 cup of chopped ash gourd (kumbalanga) , 1 cup of grated coconut , 1/2 teaspoon of turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon of cumin seeds , 2 green chilies , 1/2 cup of yogurt , Salt to taste , Water as required , For Tempering: 1 tablespoon of coconut oil , 1/2 teaspoon of mustard seeds , 2-3 dry red chilies , A few curry leaves.
instruction: In a pan, add chopped yam, raw plantains, and ash gourd along with turmeric powder, cumin seeds, green chilies, and salt. Add water just enough to cover the vegetables and cook them until they become tender. This usually takes about 15-20 minutes on medium heat. Meanwhile, grind grated coconut with a little water to make a smooth paste. Once the vegetables are cooked, add the coconut paste to the pan and mix well. Let it simmer for another 5 minutes on low heat. In a separate small pan, heat coconut oil for tempering. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Then add dry red chilies and curry leaves to the pan and fry for a few seconds. Pour this tempering over the Kaalan and mix well. Turn off the heat and let it sit for a couple of minutes. Finally, add yogurt to the Kaalan and mix gently. Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Kai Mezhukkupuratti
description: Kai Mezhukkupuratti, a traditional South Indian dish, features tender raw plantains stir-fried to perfection with aromatic spices. This flavorful and nutritious side dish is prepared by sautéing chopped plantains in coconut oil along with mustard seeds, cumin seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves. Seasoned with turmeric powder and salt, the plantains are cooked until tender and then stir-fried until lightly golden. Garnished with grated coconut for added texture, Kai Mezhukkupuratti is a delightful accompaniment to any meal, whether paired with rice or enjoyed alongside roti.
ingredients: 2 raw plantains, peeled and chopped into small cubes , 2 tablespoons coconut oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2-3 dried red chilies , 1 sprig curry leaves , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons grated coconut (optional, for garnish).
instruction: Heat coconut oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add cumin seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves. Saute for a few seconds until fragrant. Add chopped raw plantains to the pan. Stir well to coat them with the oil and spices. Sprinkle turmeric powder and salt over the plantains. Mix until evenly combined. Cover the pan and cook the plantains on low heat, stirring occasionally, until they are tender and cooked through. This usually takes about 15-20 minutes. Once the plantains are cooked, remove the lid and increase the heat to medium-high. Stir-fry for another 2-3 minutes to lightly brown the edges. Garnish with grated coconut (if using) and serve hot as a side dish with rice or roti.

name: Kallappam
description: Kallappam, also known as Vellayappam, is a traditional Kerala delicacy that delights with its soft, fluffy texture and subtle coconut flavor. Made from a blend of raw rice, cooked rice, grated coconut, and a hint of yeast, this fermented batter is poured into a pan and cooked until golden brown, resulting in a thin, lacy pancake perfect for savoring with your favorite curry or chutney. Enjoy the aroma of Kerala cuisine as you prepare this authentic dish, which is sure to become a favorite at your dining table.
ingredients: 2 cups raw rice , 1/2 cup cooked rice , 1/4 cup grated coconut , 1/4 cup cooked rice flakes (aval) , 1/2 tsp active dry yeast , 1 tsp sugar , Salt to taste , Water as needed.
instruction: Soak the raw rice in water for about 4-6 hours or overnight. Drain the water completely. In a blender, combine the soaked raw rice, cooked rice, grated coconut, cooked rice flakes, active dry yeast, sugar, and salt. Grind them together into a smooth batter. Transfer the batter into a large bowl. Cover and let it ferment for about 6-8 hours or until it doubles in volume. Once fermented, stir the batter well. If it's too thick, add a little water to achieve a pourable consistency. Heat a non-stick pan or appam pan over medium heat. Pour a ladleful of batter into the center of the pan and quickly swirl the pan to spread the batter thinly around the edges. Cover the pan and cook the kallappam for 2-3 minutes or until the edges start to crisp up and the center is cooked through. Repeat the process with the remaining batter. Serve the kallappam warm with your favorite curry or side dish.

name: Kappa (Tapioca) Puttu
description: A traditional South Indian delicacy, Kappa Puttu is a savory dish made from grated tapioca and coconut. The grated tapioca is mixed with coconut and salt, then steamed to perfection in a puttu maker or steamer. This gluten-free and vegan dish is not only delicious but also easy to prepare, making it a perfect choice for breakfast or as a wholesome snack. Enjoy the unique texture and flavors of Kappa Puttu paired with your favorite curry or chutney for a satisfying meal experience.
ingredients: 2 cups grated tapioca (kappa) , 1 cup grated coconut , Salt to taste.
instruction: Wash and peel the tapioca. Grate it finely using a grater. Take a mixing bowl and add the grated tapioca, grated coconut, and salt. Mix well until everything is combined evenly. Take a puttu maker or steamer and fill the bottom vessel with water. Place it on the stove and bring the water to a boil. Meanwhile, fill the puttu maker with alternating layers of the tapioca-coconut mixture and grated coconut. Once the water in the bottom vessel starts boiling, place the puttu maker on top of it and steam for about 10-15 minutes or until the puttu is cooked through. Once cooked, carefully remove the puttu from the puttu maker and serve hot with your favorite curry or side dish.

name: Karikku Dosa or Tender Coconut Pancake
description: Karikku Dosa, also known as Tender Coconut Pancake, is a delightful South Indian delicacy bursting with the refreshing flavor of tender coconut. Made with a blend of tender coconut water, flesh, rice flour, and grated coconut, this pancake offers a unique and tropical twist to your breakfast or snack time. Simply blend the ingredients into a smooth batter, cook them into thin, golden pancakes on a hot griddle, and enjoy the heavenly aroma and taste of Karikku Dosa. Perfect for a leisurely morning treat or a quick bite on-the-go, this recipe is sure to tantalize your taste buds with its exotic flavors and simplicity.
ingredients: 1 cup tender coconut water , 1 cup tender coconut flesh (malai) , 1 cup rice flour , 1/4 cup grated coconut , 2 tablespoons sugar (adjust to taste) , A pinch of salt , Ghee or oil for cooking.
instruction: In a blender, combine the tender coconut water, tender coconut flesh, grated coconut, sugar, and salt. Blend until smooth. Transfer the blended mixture into a mixing bowl. Add rice flour gradually while stirring continuously to avoid lumps. Mix until you get a smooth batter consistency. Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat. Brush some ghee or oil on the surface. Pour a ladleful of the batter onto the hot pan and spread it in a circular motion to form a thin pancake. Cook until the edges start to brown and the surface looks cooked, then flip the pancake and cook the other side until golden brown. Repeat the process with the remaining batter. Serve hot Karikku Dosa with your favorite chutney or as it is.

name: Kerala Banana Dessert
description: Kerala Banana Dessert is a delightful traditional delicacy that captures the essence of Kerala cuisine. Made with ripe Kerala bananas, grated coconut, jaggery, and a hint of cardamom, this dessert offers a perfect balance of sweetness and flavor. The bananas are sautéed to golden perfection, then combined with a syrupy jaggery mixture and coconut, resulting in a rich and indulgent treat. Whether enjoyed warm or chilled, this dessert is sure to tantalize your taste buds with its unique blend of ingredients and aromatic spices.
ingredients: 4 ripe Kerala bananas , 1 cup grated coconut , 1/2 cup jaggery (or to taste) , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , 2 tablespoons ghee (clarified butter) , A pinch of salt.
instruction: Peel the bananas and cut them into small pieces. In a pan, heat 1 tablespoon of ghee over medium heat. Add the chopped bananas to the pan and sauté them until they turn slightly golden brown. In another pan, melt the jaggery with a little water to form a syrup. Strain to remove impurities if necessary. Add the jaggery syrup to the pan with the bananas and mix well. Add the grated coconut, cardamom powder, and a pinch of salt to the pan. Stir everything together. Cook the mixture for a few more minutes until it thickens and the flavors blend well. Add the remaining tablespoon of ghee to the pan and mix it in. Once the dessert reaches the desired consistency and the flavors meld together, remove it from the heat. Serve the Kerala Banana Dessert warm or cold, as per your preference.

name: Koottu Kari
description: A delectable South Indian dish, Koottu Kari is a hearty blend of mixed vegetables and lentils, seasoned with a fragrant mix of spices. This wholesome curry, bursting with flavors, features a medley of carrots, beans, peas, and potatoes, cooked to perfection with chana dal and toor dal. Seasoned with mustard seeds, cumin seeds, and curry leaves, and infused with the subtle heat of green chilies, this dish is a delightful addition to any meal. Serve Koottu Kari hot with rice or chapati for a satisfying culinary experience.
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrot, beans, peas, potato), chopped , 1/2 cup chana dal (split chickpeas) , 1/2 cup toor dal (split pigeon peas) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, slit , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Few curry leaves , 2 tablespoons oil , Salt to taste , Coriander leaves for garnish.
instruction: Wash and soak chana dal and toor dal in water for 30 minutes. Pressure cook soaked dals with chopped vegetables, turmeric powder, salt, and enough water for 3-4 whistles or until dals are cooked well. Once the pressure releases, mash the cooked dals and vegetables lightly. Keep aside. Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add cumin seeds, asafoetida, and curry leaves. Saute for a few seconds. Add chopped onions and green chilies. Saute until onions turn translucent. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Now, add the mashed dal-vegetable mixture to the pan. Mix well. Adjust salt if needed and let it simmer for 5-7 minutes on low heat. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or chapati.

name: Kottayam Churuttu
description: A traditional Kerala delicacy, Kottayam Churuttu is a delightful snack made from rice flour, grated coconut, and aromatic spices. The dough is shaped into small cylinders, wrapped in banana leaves, and steamed to perfection. This savory treat is bursting with flavors and is perfect for snacking or as a side dish with your favorite curry. Enjoy the authentic taste of Kerala cuisine with this easy-to-make and delicious Kottayam Churuttu recipe.
ingredients: 1 cup rice flour , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 1/4 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/4 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon salt (or to taste) , Water, as needed , Banana leaves or parchment paper, for wrapping.
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the rice flour, grated coconut, cumin seeds, turmeric powder, and salt. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. The dough should be firm yet pliable. Take a small portion of the dough and roll it into a cylindrical shape, about 3-4 inches long. Place the dough cylinder on a piece of banana leaf or parchment paper and wrap it tightly, securing the ends. Repeat the process with the remaining dough. Steam the wrapped dough cylinders in a steamer for about 15-20 minutes, or until cooked through. Once cooked, remove the churuttu from the steamer and let them cool slightly before unwrapping. Serve warm as a snack or with your favorite curry.

name: Kurumulaku Kanji or Pepper Porridge
description: Kurumulaku Kanji (Pepper Porridge) is a traditional South Indian dish that offers both warmth and comfort. Made with rice, coconut, and a blend of spices including black peppercorns and cumin seeds, this porridge is a soothing and nutritious option for any time of the day. It's easy to prepare and packed with flavor, making it a popular choice during cold weather or when feeling under the weather. Give yourself a culinary hug with a bowl of Kurumulaku Kanji!
ingredients: 1/2 cup rice , 4 cups water , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 1 tablespoon black peppercorns , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2 cloves garlic, minced , Salt, to taste.
instruction: Rinse the rice thoroughly under running water until the water runs clear. In a pot, combine the rice and water. Bring it to a boil over medium heat. Reduce the heat to low and let the rice cook until it is soft and mushy, stirring occasionally. This usually takes about 30-40 minutes. While the rice is cooking, grind the grated coconut, black peppercorns, cumin seeds, and minced garlic into a fine paste using a blender or mortar and pestle. Once the rice is cooked, add the ground coconut paste to the pot. Stir well to combine and let it simmer for another 10-15 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld together. Season with salt to taste and adjust the consistency by adding more water if needed. Remove from heat and serve hot.

name: Madhura Kizhangu Uppumavu
description: A delightful South Indian dish made from sweet potatoes, semolina, and a blend of spices. The sweet potatoes lend a subtle sweetness to the dish, while the roasted semolina adds a nutty flavor and satisfying texture. This comforting dish is easy to prepare and perfect for a wholesome breakfast or a light meal. With its aromatic spices and hearty ingredients, Madhura Kizhangu Uppumavu is sure to be a favorite among both kids and adults alike.
ingredients: 2 medium-sized sweet potatoes (Madhura Kizhangu), peeled and diced , 1 cup semolina (rava) , 2 cups water , 2 tablespoons coconut oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, chopped , 1 sprig curry leaves , 1/4 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnishing (optional).
instruction: In a pan, dry roast the semolina (rava) over medium heat until it turns golden brown and fragrant. Remove from heat and set aside. In a separate pot, boil the diced sweet potatoes in water until they are soft and tender. Drain and mash them using a fork or potato masher. Set aside. In a large skillet or kadai, heat coconut oil over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. Allow them to splutter. Add chopped onions, green chilies, and curry leaves. Saute until the onions turn translucent. Add the mashed sweet potatoes to the skillet along with turmeric powder and salt. Mix well to combine. Gradually add the roasted semolina (rava) to the sweet potato mixture while stirring continuously to avoid lumps. Cook the mixture for a few minutes until everything is well combined and the semolina is cooked through. If the mixture is too dry, you can add a little more water. Once done, remove from heat and garnish with fresh coriander leaves, if desired. Serve hot as is or with a side of chutney or pickle.

name: Making of Ada
description: Ada, a traditional South Indian delicacy, is a delightful treat enjoyed by many. This sweet and savory dish features thin, rice flour discs filled with a delicious mixture of grated coconut and jaggery, flavored with aromatic cardamom. The dough is skillfully shaped and steamed until tender, resulting in a delectable snack bursting with flavor. Perfect for any occasion, Ada is a beloved favorite that never fails to satisfy cravings for authentic South Indian cuisine.
ingredients: 1 cup rice flour , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 1/4 cup jaggery (or as per taste) , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , Water, as needed , Banana leaves or parchment paper for wrapping.
instruction: Prepare the Dough: In a mixing bowl, combine rice flour, grated coconut, jaggery, and cardamom powder. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. The dough should be soft and pliable. Shape the Ada: Divide the dough into small portions and roll them into balls. Flatten each ball into thin, round discs on banana leaves or parchment paper. Steam the Ada: Steam the flattened discs in a steamer for about 5-7 minutes until they are cooked through. They should become slightly translucent. Serve: Remove the Ada from the steamer and let them cool slightly. Serve warm or at room temperature.

name: Mezhukkupuratty
description: Mezhukkupuratty is a traditional Kerala stir-fry dish bursting with flavors and aromas. Made with a medley of fresh vegetables, such as beans, carrots, and potatoes, this dish is cooked in aromatic coconut oil with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and garlic, lending it a delightful crunch and a burst of spice. The vegetables are cooked until tender yet retaining their natural texture, resulting in a deliciously comforting side dish that pairs perfectly with rice or roti. Enjoy the vibrant colors and tantalizing flavors of Mezhukkupuratty for a wholesome and satisfying meal.
ingredients: 2 cups of vegetables (such as beans, carrots, potatoes, or cabbage), chopped into small pieces , 2 tablespoons coconut oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 sprig curry leaves , 2-3 dried red chilies, broken into pieces , 2-3 cloves of garlic, finely chopped , 1 small onion, thinly sliced , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste.
instruction: Heat coconut oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add curry leaves, dried red chilies, and chopped garlic. Sauté for a minute until fragrant. Add thinly sliced onions and sauté until they turn golden brown. Add the chopped vegetables, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well. Cover the pan and cook for about 8-10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are cooked but still retain their crunchiness. Once the vegetables are cooked, remove the lid and continue to cook for another 2-3 minutes until any excess moisture evaporates and the stir-fry becomes dry. Remove from heat and serve hot as a side dish with rice or roti.

name: Olan
description: Olan is a traditional Kerala dish that offers a delightful blend of flavors and textures. This simple yet flavorful recipe combines diced white pumpkin, ash gourd, and soaked cowpeas, simmered together with slit green chilies, turmeric powder, and salt until tender. The addition of thick coconut milk adds richness and creaminess to the dish, while a fragrant tempering of curry leaves in coconut oil enhances its aroma and taste. Olan is best enjoyed hot, served alongside steamed rice for a wholesome and satisfying meal.
ingredients: 1 cup white pumpkin, diced , 1/2 cup ash gourd, diced , 1/2 cup cowpeas (van payar), soaked overnight , 2-3 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1 cup thick coconut milk , 1/2 tsp turmeric powder , Salt to taste , 1 tbsp coconut oil , Curry leaves for garnish.
instruction: In a large pot, combine diced white pumpkin, ash gourd, and soaked cowpeas. Add slit green chilies, turmeric powder, and salt to taste. Pour enough water to cover the vegetables and cowpeas. Place the pot on medium heat and bring it to a gentle boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low and let it simmer until the vegetables and cowpeas are cooked through and tender. This usually takes about 20-25 minutes. Once the vegetables and cowpeas are cooked, add thick coconut milk to the pot and mix well. Let it simmer for another 5 minutes on low heat, stirring occasionally. In a separate small pan, heat coconut oil. Add curry leaves and fry until crispy. Pour this tempering over the olan and mix gently. Turn off the heat and transfer the olan to a serving dish. Serve hot with steamed rice for a delicious South Indian meal.

name: Paal Paayasam
description: Paal Paayasam, a traditional South Indian dessert, is a creamy and aromatic rice pudding simmered in milk and sweetened with sugar. Fragrant with cardamom and garnished with crunchy cashews and golden raisins, it offers a delightful blend of flavors and textures. Served warm or chilled, this indulgent treat is perfect for celebrations or as a comforting dessert after a hearty meal.
ingredients: 1/2 cup Basmati rice , 4 cups whole milk , 1/2 cup sugar (adjust to taste) , 1/4 teaspoon crushed cardamom seeds , 10-12 cashew nuts, chopped , 10-12 golden raisins , 1 tablespoon ghee (clarified butter) , A pinch of saffron strands (optional) , A few strands of pistachios, chopped (for garnish) , A few strands of almonds, chopped (for garnish).
instruction: Rinse the rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain and set aside. In a heavy-bottomed pan, heat the ghee over medium heat. Add the cashew nuts and raisins. Fry until the cashews turn golden brown and the raisins plump up. Remove them from the pan and set aside. In the same pan, add the rinsed rice and sauté for a couple of minutes until it turns slightly translucent. Pour in the milk and stir well. Bring the mixture to a gentle boil, then reduce the heat to low. Simmer the rice and milk mixture, stirring occasionally, until the rice is fully cooked and the mixture thickens to a creamy consistency. This may take about 30-40 minutes. Once the rice is cooked, add the sugar and crushed cardamom seeds. Stir well to combine and dissolve the sugar. If using saffron, dissolve it in a tablespoon of warm milk and add it to the kheer for a rich color and aroma. Stir well. Add the fried cashews and raisins to the kheer and mix gently. Remove the pan from the heat and allow the kheer to cool slightly. Garnish with chopped pistachios and almonds. Serve warm or chilled, as desired.

name: Palada Pradhaman
description: Palada Pradhaman is a traditional Kerala dessert made with rice ada, milk, jaggery, and flavored with cardamom. The rice ada is cooked until soft and translucent, then simmered in jaggery syrup and milk until it thickens to a creamy consistency. Garnished with fried cashew nuts and raisins, this decadent dessert is a delightful treat enjoyed during festivals and special occasions in South India.
ingredients: 1 cup Palada (rice ada) , 4 cups Milk , 1 cup Jaggery (grated) , 2 tablespoons Ghee (clarified butter) , 10-15 Cashew nuts , 10-15 Raisins , 4-5 Cardamom pods (crushed) , A pinch of Salt.
instruction: Prepare the Palada: Soak the Palada (rice ada) in water for about 30 minutes. Drain the water and keep the soaked Palada aside. Cooking Palada: In a large pot, bring 4 cups of water to a boil. Add the soaked Palada to the boiling water and cook until it becomes soft and translucent. This may take about 20-25 minutes. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking. Once cooked, drain the excess water and rinse the cooked Palada under cold water to stop the cooking process. Keep it aside. Prepare the Jaggery Syrup: In a separate saucepan, heat the grated jaggery with a little water over medium heat. Stir continuously until the jaggery completely dissolves and forms a syrup. Then, strain the syrup to remove any impurities. Cooking Palada Pradhaman: In a deep-bottomed pan, heat ghee over medium heat. Add cashew nuts and raisins, and sauté until they turn golden brown. Remove them from the pan and keep aside. In the same pan, add the cooked Palada and jaggery syrup. Mix well. Gradually add milk while stirring continuously. Allow it to simmer over low heat until the mixture thickens and attains a creamy consistency. Add crushed cardamom pods and a pinch of salt for flavor. Once the Palada Pradhaman reaches the desired consistency, turn off the heat. Serve: Garnish with the fried cashew nuts and raisins. Palada Pradhaman can be served hot or cold as per preference.

name: Pantithal
description: A traditional South Indian delight, Pantithal is a simple yet flavorful dish that brings together rice flour, grated coconut, jaggery, and a pinch of salt. These ingredients are kneaded into a smooth dough, shaped into small discs, and then cooked on a griddle until golden brown. Served warm, Pantithal pairs perfectly with coconut chutney or any favorite dipping sauce. With its crispy exterior and soft, chewy texture inside, Pantithal is a delightful treat for any occasion.
ingredients: 1 cup rice flour , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 1/4 cup jaggery (or to taste) , 1/4 teaspoon salt , Water, as needed , Ghee or oil, for cooking.
instruction: Prepare the Dough: In a mixing bowl, combine the rice flour, grated coconut, jaggery, and salt. Gradually add water while kneading to form a smooth dough. The consistency should be similar to that of chapati dough. Shape the Pantithal: Divide the dough into small portions and roll each portion into a ball. Flatten each ball with your palms to form a disc shape, about 1/4 inch thick. Cook the Pantithal: Heat a griddle or skillet over medium heat and lightly grease it with ghee or oil. Place the flattened Pantithal on the griddle and cook for about 2-3 minutes on each side until golden brown and cooked through. Repeat the process with the remaining dough. Serve: Serve the Pantithal warm with a side of coconut chutney or any other dipping sauce of your choice.

name: Pappadam Thoran
description: Pappadam Thoran is a delightful South Indian dish that combines crispy pappadams with a fragrant mixture of grated coconut, onions, green chilies, and spices. The roasted pappadams add a crunchy texture to the dish, while the coconut lends a subtle sweetness. Mustard seeds, cumin seeds, and curry leaves infuse the thoran with aromatic flavors, making it a perfect accompaniment to steamed rice or as a standalone snack. With its quick preparation and irresistible taste, Pappadam Thoran is sure to become a favorite in your kitchen.
ingredients: 4-5 large pappadams , 1 cup grated coconut , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2-3 green chilies, chopped , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2-3 dry red chilies , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Curry leaves , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon oil.
instruction: Roast the pappadams over an open flame until they are crisp. Break them into small pieces and set aside. Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter. Add cumin seeds, dry red chilies, and curry leaves. Saute for a few seconds. Add chopped onion and green chilies. Cook until the onions turn golden brown. Add grated coconut and saute for a couple of minutes until it turns light golden. Now, add the roasted pappadam pieces and mix well. Add salt to taste and a pinch of asafoetida. Mix everything thoroughly. Cook for another 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally. Once done, remove from heat and serve hot as a side dish with rice or enjoy it as a snack.

name: Parippu Curry
description: A traditional South Indian dish, Parippu Curry, also known as Lentil Curry, is a comforting and flavorful recipe made with split pigeon peas (toor dal), onions, green chilies, and aromatic spices. The lentils are cooked to perfection, then tempered with mustard seeds, dry red chilies, and curry leaves in coconut oil for added flavor. This hearty and nutritious curry pairs wonderfully with steamed rice or chapati, making it a wholesome meal option for any day of the week.
ingredients: 1 cup split pigeon peas (toor dal) , 2 cups water , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, slit , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , For Tempering: 2 tablespoons coconut oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 2 dry red chilies , 1 sprig curry leaves , For Garnish: Fresh coriander leaves, chopped.
instruction: Rinse the split pigeon peas (toor dal) under running water until the water runs clear. In a pressure cooker, combine the rinsed toor dal, water, chopped onion, green chilies, turmeric powder, and salt. Close the pressure cooker with its lid and cook the dal mixture over medium heat for about 3-4 whistles or until the dal is soft and cooked through. Once the pressure releases naturally, open the cooker and give the dal a good stir. If it's too thick, add a little water to adjust the consistency. For tempering, heat coconut oil in a small pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Then add dry red chilies and curry leaves. Fry until the curry leaves turn crisp and aromatic. Pour the tempering over the cooked dal and mix well. Garnish the Parippu Curry with freshly chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with steamed rice or chapati.

name: Pathiri
description: A traditional South Indian delicacy, Pathiri is a versatile flatbread made with rice flour, coconut, and cumin seeds. The dough is kneaded to perfection, rolled into thin circles, and cooked on a hot griddle until golden brown and crispy. Served hot, these Pathiris are perfect accompaniments to a variety of curries or enjoyed on their own. With a preparation time of just 15 minutes and cooking time of 20 minutes, this recipe yields 4 servings, with each serving containing approximately 150 calories. Enjoy the delightful flavors of Pathiri, a comforting addition to any meal.
ingredients: 2 cups rice flour , 1 cup grated coconut , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , Salt, to taste , Water, as needed , Ghee or oil, for cooking.
instruction: Prepare the Dough: In a mixing bowl, combine the rice flour, grated coconut, cumin seeds, and salt. Gradually add water and knead into a smooth dough. The dough should be soft but not too sticky. Divide the dough into small portions and shape them into balls. Roll Out the Pathiris: Take a dough ball and flatten it into a small disc using a rolling pin. Alternatively, you can use your hands to flatten the dough into thin circles. Cook the Pathiris: Heat a griddle or a non-stick pan over medium heat. Place the flattened pathiri on the hot griddle and cook for a few seconds on each side until small bubbles start to appear. Brush with ghee or oil on both sides and cook until golden brown spots appear, flipping as needed. Serve: Serve the pathiris hot with your favorite curry or side dish.

name: Pazham Pulissery
description: Pazham Pulissery is a traditional South Indian dish that tantalizes the taste buds with its unique blend of flavors. Ripe bananas are simmered in a creamy coconut and yogurt sauce, infused with the warmth of turmeric and the subtle heat of green chilies. Tempered mustard seeds and curry leaves add a final flourish, elevating the dish to culinary perfection. This delightful recipe is a harmonious marriage of sweet and savory, making it a favorite among food enthusiasts.
ingredients: Ripe bananas (Pazham) - 2 large, peeled and sliced , Yogurt (Curd) - 1 cup , Coconut - 1/2 cup, grated , Green chilies - 2, slit , Turmeric powder - 1/4 teaspoon , Cumin seeds - 1/2 teaspoon , Mustard seeds - 1/2 teaspoon , Curry leaves - a few , Red chili powder - 1/2 teaspoon (optional) , Salt - to taste , Water - as needed , Coconut oil - 1 tablespoon.
instruction: In a blender, grind the grated coconut, green chilies, turmeric powder, and cumin seeds into a smooth paste by adding a little water. In a deep pan, add the sliced bananas, water, and salt. Cook until the bananas are soft. Add the ground coconut paste to the cooked bananas and mix well. Let it simmer for a few minutes. Beat the yogurt well and add it to the pan. Stir continuously on low heat for about 5 minutes. Do not let it boil. In a separate small pan, heat coconut oil. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Then add curry leaves and red chili powder (if using). Pour this tempering over the prepared Pazham Pulissery. Stir well and remove from heat. Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Pazhampori (Banana Fritter)
description: A beloved South Indian snack, Pazhampori tantalizes taste buds with its crispy exterior and soft, sweet interior. Ripe bananas are sliced, coated in a golden batter infused with turmeric and sugar, then fried to perfection in coconut oil. The result? Irresistible fritters that strike the perfect balance between savory and sweet, making them an ideal accompaniment to a hot cup of tea or a delightful snack any time of day.
ingredients: Ripe bananas - 4 large , All-purpose flour (maida) - 1 cup , Rice flour - 2 tablespoons , Sugar - 2 tablespoons (adjust to taste) , Turmeric powder - 1/4 teaspoon , Baking soda - 1/4 teaspoon , Salt - a pinch , Water - as needed , Coconut oil - for frying.
instruction: Peel the bananas and slice them lengthwise into halves or quarters, depending on the size of the bananas. In a mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, rice flour, sugar, turmeric powder, baking soda, and a pinch of salt. Gradually add water to the dry ingredients and mix well to form a smooth batter. The consistency should be similar to pancake batter. Heat coconut oil in a deep frying pan or kadai over medium heat. Dip each banana slice into the batter, ensuring it is evenly coated. Carefully place the coated banana slices into the hot oil and fry until they turn golden brown and crispy on both sides. Once done, remove the Pazhampori from the oil and drain excess oil on paper towels. Serve hot Pazhampori with tea or as a snack.

name: Pineapple Pachadi
description: Pineapple Pachadi is a delightful South Indian dish that combines the sweet and tangy flavors of pineapple with a creamy coconut yogurt base. This refreshing dish is made by blending chopped pineapple, grated coconut, yogurt, and spices until smooth. It is then tempered with mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, curry leaves, and red chilies to enhance its flavor. Pineapple Pachadi is perfect as a side dish with rice or as a condiment to complement a variety of meals.
ingredients: 2 cups chopped pineapple , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 1/2 cup yogurt , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2-3 green chilies, chopped , A pinch of turmeric powder , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon oil , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon fenugreek seeds , 1-2 dry red chilies , A few curry leaves , 1/4 teaspoon asafoetida , 1 teaspoon sugar (optional).
instruction: In a blender, combine chopped pineapple, grated coconut, yogurt, mustard seeds, cumin seeds, chopped green chilies, turmeric powder, and salt. Blend until smooth. Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dry red chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida. Let them splutter. Pour the blended pineapple mixture into the pan. Stir well and cook for 2-3 minutes on low heat. Add sugar if desired and mix well. Adjust the seasoning according to taste. Remove from heat and transfer to a serving bowl. Garnish with fresh curry leaves. Serve Pineapple Pachadi with rice or as a side dish with your favorite meal.

name: Ponnankanni (Koyipachappu)
description: This nutritious and flavorful dish combines fresh Ponnanganni leaves with toor dal and aromatic spices. After cooking the dal to a creamy consistency, it's mixed with sautéed Ponnanganni leaves infused with mustard seeds, cumin, and green chilies for a burst of flavor. With a dash of turmeric and a pinch of asafoetida for added depth, this dish is both wholesome and satisfying. Enjoy it with steamed rice or chapati for a wholesome meal that's as comforting as it is delicious.
ingredients: 1 cup Ponnanganni (Alternanthera sessilis) leaves, washed and chopped , 1/2 cup toor dal (split pigeon peas), washed , 2 cups water , 2-3 green chilies, chopped , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2-3 dry red chilies , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish (optional).
instruction: In a pressure cooker, add washed toor dal and 2 cups of water. Cook the dal until it is soft and mushy, usually takes about 3-4 whistles on medium heat. Once done, mash the dal well and set aside. Heat oil in a pan or kadhai over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add cumin seeds, dry red chilies, and green chilies to the pan. Saute for a minute until fragrant. Add chopped Ponnanganni leaves to the pan along with turmeric powder and salt. Mix well. Cook the Ponnanganni leaves for about 5-7 minutes until they are tender and cooked through. Once the leaves are cooked, add the mashed dal to the pan and mix everything together. Adjust the consistency of the curry by adding water if needed. Let the curry simmer for another 2-3 minutes. In a small pan, heat a teaspoon of oil. Add a pinch of asafoetida and pour it over the curry. Mix well. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves if desired. Serve hot with steamed rice or chapati.

name: Pulissery
description: Pulissery is a traditional South Indian dish that tantalizes the taste buds with its unique blend of flavors. This delightful recipe combines ripe mangoes with tangy yogurt, infused with aromatic spices and tempered to perfection. The creamy texture of the yogurt complements the sweetness of the mangoes, while the tempering adds a burst of flavor with mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, and curry leaves. Served hot alongside steamed rice, Pulissery is a comforting and wholesome dish that is sure to leave you craving for more.
ingredients: 1 ripe mango, peeled and diced , 1 cup yogurt (preferably sour) , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , For Tempering: 1 tablespoon coconut oil , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon fenugreek seeds , 2-3 dry red chilies , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Few curry leaves , For Grinding: 1/2 cup grated coconut , 1 green chili.
instruction: Prepare the Mango: In a saucepan, add diced mango along with a little water. Cook until the mango is soft and mushy. Make the Coconut Paste: In a blender, grind grated coconut and green chili into a smooth paste by adding a little water. Keep it aside. Mix Yogurt: In a bowl, whisk yogurt until smooth. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well. Combine Mango and Yogurt: Add the cooked mango to the yogurt mixture and mix well. Tempering: Heat coconut oil in a small pan. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Then add fenugreek seeds, dry red chilies, asafoetida, and curry leaves. Fry for a few seconds until aromatic. Combine Everything: Pour the tempering over the mango-yogurt mixture and mix well. Final Touch: Heat the pulissery gently on low heat for a few minutes, stirring occasionally. Make sure not to boil it. Serve: Serve the pulissery hot with steamed rice.

name: Kadala Curry
description: Kadala Curry is a rich and spicy curry made with black chickpeas cooked in a coconut-based gravy infused with aromatic spices like mustard seeds, curry leaves, and coconut milk.
ingredients: 1 cup black chickpeas (kala chana), soaked overnight , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 2 green chilies, slit , 1 sprig curry leaves , 1-inch ginger, grated , 3 cloves garlic, minced , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish.
instruction: Heat oil in a pressure cooker. Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. Let them crackle. Add chopped onions, green chilies, ginger, garlic, and curry leaves. Saute until onions turn golden brown. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well. Add soaked black chickpeas and stir to coat them with the masala. Add enough water to cover the chickpeas. Close the pressure cooker lid and cook for 6-7 whistles or until the chickpeas are cooked through. Once the pressure releases, open the lid and simmer the curry until it thickens slightly. Sprinkle garam masala and garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with Puttu.

name: Puttu
description: Puttu and Kadala Curry is a classic South Indian dish that combines steamed rice flour cylinders (Puttu) with a flavorful black chickpea curry (Kadala Curry). Puttu, a staple breakfast item, is made by layering moistened rice flour with grated coconut and steaming it in cylindrical bamboo or metal molds.
ingredients: 2 cups rice flour , 1/2 cup grated coconut , Salt to taste , Water, as needed.
instruction: In a bowl, mix the rice flour with salt and enough water to make a moist crumbly mixture. Layer the bottom of a puttu maker or steamer with grated coconut. Fill the puttu maker with alternating layers of the rice mixture and grated coconut, ending with grated coconut on top. Steam for about 10-12 minutes until cooked through. Serve hot with Kadala Curry.

name: Rasam
description: Rasam, a traditional South Indian soup, is a delightful blend of tangy tamarind, aromatic spices, and lentils. This flavorful dish is a staple in many households, often enjoyed as a comforting soup or paired with steamed rice. With its vibrant color and refreshing taste, Rasam is known for its ability to awaken the senses and soothe the soul. Whether served hot on a chilly day or as a refreshing appetizer, Rasam never fails to delight with its simple yet irresistible charm.
ingredients: 1/2 cup split pigeon peas (toor dal) , 2 medium-sized tomatoes, chopped , 1 small lemon-sized ball of tamarind , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon black pepper corns , 2-3 dried red chilies , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon asafoetida (hing) , 1 tablespoon ghee or oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , Few curry leaves , Salt to taste , Chopped coriander leaves for garnish.
instruction: Cooking the Dal: Rinse the split pigeon peas (toor dal) under water until the water runs clear. Pressure cook the dal with enough water until it is soft and mushy. Set aside. Preparing Tamarind Extract: Soak the tamarind in warm water for about 10 minutes. Squeeze the tamarind to extract its pulp. Discard the seeds and fibers. Making Rasam Paste: In a blender, combine the chopped tomatoes, cumin seeds, black pepper corns, dried red chilies, turmeric powder, and asafoetida. Blend until smooth. Cooking Rasam: Heat ghee or oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and let them crackle. Add curry leaves and sauté for a few seconds. Pour the blended tomato mixture into the pan and cook for a few minutes until the raw smell disappears. Add the tamarind extract and mix well. Let it simmer for 5-7 minutes. Add the cooked dal and salt to taste. Mix everything well and let it simmer for another 5 minutes. Garnishing and Serving: Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot Rasam as a soup or with steamed rice.

name: Roasted Coconut Chutney
description: Elevate your South Indian culinary experience with this delectable Roasted Coconut Chutney. Made with freshly grated coconut, roasted chana dal, and a blend of aromatic spices, this chutney boasts a rich and nutty flavor profile. Perfectly roasted coconut lends a delightful crunch while green chilies and ginger add a hint of warmth and zing. Quick and easy to prepare, this chutney pairs wonderfully with dosa, idli, vada, or any South Indian dish, adding a burst of flavor to every bite. Enjoy the authentic taste of South India with this irresistible Roasted Coconut Chutney!
ingredients: 1 cup grated coconut (fresh or desiccated) , 2 tablespoons roasted chana dal (split chickpeas) , 2-3 green chilies, chopped , 1 small piece of ginger, chopped , 1 tablespoon oil , ½ teaspoon mustard seeds , ½ teaspoon cumin seeds , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Salt to taste , Water as needed , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish (optional).
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add cumin seeds and asafoetida. Stir for a few seconds until fragrant. Add grated coconut to the pan and roast it for about 4-5 minutes until it turns golden brown. Keep stirring continuously to avoid burning. Once the coconut is roasted, transfer it to a plate and let it cool down. In a blender or food processor, add the roasted coconut, roasted chana dal, green chilies, ginger, and salt. Blend the mixture into a coarse paste, adding a little water as needed to achieve the desired consistency. Transfer the chutney to a serving bowl. For the tempering, heat a small amount of oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Pour this tempering over the chutney. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves if desired. Serve the roasted coconut chutney as a side dish with dosa, idli, vada, or any South Indian snack of your choice.

name: Sambar
description: Sambar, a beloved South Indian staple, is a flavorful and comforting lentil-based stew enriched with a medley of vegetables and aromatic spices. This hearty dish combines the wholesome goodness of toor dal with the tangy notes of tamarind and the earthy warmth of sambar powder. The result is a deliciously balanced concoction that pairs perfectly with steamed rice, idli, or dosa. Whether enjoyed as a comforting meal at home or shared with friends and family, Sambar never fails to delight the taste buds with its rich flavors and nourishing goodness.
ingredients: 1 cup toor dal (split pigeon peas) , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 1 medium tomato, chopped , 1 small carrot, chopped , 1 small potato, diced , 1 drumstick, cut into pieces (optional) , 1/2 cup tamarind extract , 2 tablespoons sambar powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Few curry leaves , 2 dry red chilies , 2 green chilies, slit , 2 tablespoons chopped coriander leaves (cilantro).
instruction: Wash the toor dal thoroughly and pressure cook it with enough water until soft and mushy. Set aside. In a large pot, heat oil over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Then, add cumin seeds, asafoetida, dry red chilies, and curry leaves. Sauté for a few seconds. Add chopped onion and green chilies. Sauté until the onions turn translucent. Add chopped tomato and cook until it becomes mushy. Now, add chopped carrot, potato, and drumstick (if using). Cook for a few minutes. Add tamarind extract, sambar powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well and let it simmer for 10-15 minutes until the vegetables are cooked through. Once the vegetables are cooked, add the cooked toor dal and mix well. Adjust the consistency by adding water if needed. Let the sambar simmer for another 5-10 minutes until it reaches the desired consistency. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and turn off the heat. Serve hot with steamed rice or idli/dosa.

name: Theeyal
description: A traditional South Indian delicacy, Theeyal is a flavorful curry made with roasted coconut, spices, and tamarind, creating a rich and aromatic gravy. The blend of shallots, dried red chillies, and fenugreek seeds adds depth to the dish, while the tanginess from the tamarind balances the flavors perfectly. Served hot with steamed rice or chapati, Theeyal is a comforting and satisfying meal that captures the essence of Kerala cuisine in every bite.
ingredients: 1 cup grated coconut , 5-6 shallots, thinly sliced , 1 onion, thinly sliced , 4-5 dried red chillies , 1 teaspoon coriander seeds , 1/2 teaspoon fenugreek seeds , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/4 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chilli powder , Tamarind pulp (size of a small lemon) , 2-3 tablespoons coconut oil , 1 sprig curry leaves , Salt to taste , Water as needed.
instruction: Heat 1 tablespoon of coconut oil in a pan and roast grated coconut, shallots, dried red chillies, coriander seeds, fenugreek seeds, and mustard seeds until golden brown. Allow it to cool. Grind the roasted mixture into a fine paste using a little water. In the same pan, heat the remaining coconut oil. Add sliced onions and curry leaves. Sauté until onions turn golden brown. Add the ground paste to the pan and mix well. Cook for 2-3 minutes. Dilute tamarind pulp in water and add it to the pan along with turmeric powder, red chilli powder, and salt. Mix well. Add more water to achieve the desired consistency of the gravy. Allow the gravy to simmer for 10-15 minutes on low heat until it thickens and the flavors meld together. Adjust salt and spice levels according to taste. Serve hot with steamed rice or chapati.

name: Unniyappam
description: Unniyappam, a traditional South Indian sweet treat, is a delectable snack enjoyed by many. Made from a batter of rice flour, ripe bananas, jaggery, and coconut, these bite-sized delights are fried to golden perfection in a special Unniyappam pan. Infused with the fragrant aroma of cardamom and the sweetness of ripe bananas, each Unniyappam offers a delightful blend of flavors and textures. Whether savored as a snack with a cup of tea or served as a dessert during festive occasions, Unniyappam never fails to captivate with its irresistible taste and charm.
ingredients: 1 cup rice flour , 1/2 cup ripe mashed bananas , 1/4 cup jaggery, grated or powdered , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , 1/4 cup grated coconut , A pinch of salt , Ghee or oil for frying.
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine rice flour, mashed bananas, grated jaggery, cardamom powder, grated coconut, and a pinch of salt. Mix well to form a smooth batter. Heat the Unniyappam pan (appe pan) and grease each mould with a little ghee or oil. Pour a spoonful of batter into each mould, filling them up to 3/4th full. Cook on medium-low heat for about 2-3 minutes until the bottom side turns golden brown. Flip each Unniyappam using a skewer or spoon and cook the other side until golden brown and crispy. Once cooked, remove the Unniyappams from the pan and place them on a paper towel to absorb excess oil. Repeat the process with the remaining batter. Serve the delicious Unniyappams warm with a cup of tea or coffee.

name: Mushroom Do Pyaza
description: Mushroom Do Pyaza is a delightful vegetarian dish featuring tender mushrooms cooked with an abundance of onions. This aromatic dish combines the earthy flavors of mushrooms with the sweet and tangy essence of onions, creating a perfect balance of taste and texture. Infused with a blend of aromatic spices, it offers a burst of flavors in every bite. Whether served with rice or roti, Mushroom Do Pyaza is sure to tantalize your taste buds and leave you craving for more.
ingredients: 500g mushrooms, cleaned and sliced , 2 onions, thinly sliced , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped (adjust to taste) , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste) , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnishing.
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add sliced onions and sauté until they turn golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and chopped green chilies. Sauté for a minute until the raw smell disappears. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes. Add sliced mushrooms and mix until they are coated with the masala mixture. Cover and cook for 8-10 minutes or until the mushrooms are tender and cooked through, stirring occasionally. Once the mushrooms are cooked, uncover the pan and cook for another 2-3 minutes to evaporate any excess moisture. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Gajar Matar Ki Sabji
description: Gajar Matar Ki Sabzi is a classic Indian comfort food. Tender carrots and green peas are simmered in a warm tapestry of spices, often including cumin, coriander, and turmeric. This simple yet flavorful dish pairs perfectly with rotis or rice for a satisfying vegetarian meal.
ingredients: 2 cups grated carrots , 1 cup peas , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 2 green chilies, chopped (optional) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Add grated carrots and peas. Mix well. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix everything thoroughly. Cover and cook on medium heat until the vegetables are cooked through, stirring occasionally. Once the vegetables are cooked, add garam masala and mix well. Cook for another 2-3 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with chapati or rice.

name: Ajwain Paratha
description: Ajwain Paratha elevates the humble flatbread with a touch of intrigue. Carom seeds, with their earthy aroma, are kneaded into whole wheat dough. Ghee or oil adds richness as the dough is layered and folded, creating delightful flakiness. Cooked to a golden crisp, these savory parcels are perfect for mopping up flavorful dips.
ingredients: 2 cups whole wheat flour , 1 tablespoon ajwain (carom seeds) , Salt to taste , Water for kneading , Ghee or oil for cooking
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour, ajwain seeds, and salt. Slowly add water and knead the mixture into a soft dough. Let it rest for 15 minutes. Divide the dough into 4 equal portions and roll each portion into a ball. Take one dough ball and roll it out into a small circle using a rolling pin and some dry flour for dusting. Heat a tawa or skillet over medium heat and place the rolled-out dough circle on it. Cook for about a minute until small bubbles appear on the surface, then flip it over. Spread some ghee or oil on the cooked side and flip again. Spread ghee or oil on the other side now and cook until both sides are golden brown and crispy. Repeat the same process for the remaining dough portions. Serve hot Ajwain Parathas with yogurt, pickle, or any curry of your choice.

name: Veg Chilli Milli
description: Veg Chilli Milli is a vegetarian take on the popular Indo-Chinese dish, Chilli Chicken. Imagine bite-sized pieces of cauliflower, bell peppers, and onions, all tossed in a sweet, tangy, and spicy sauce that tingles your taste buds. The crispy fried vegetables are bathed in a flavorful concoction, creating a delightful contrast between textures. This dish is sure to satisfy your cravings for something flavorful and exciting.
ingredients: 2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, bell peppers, beans, corn) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 3 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch ginger, grated , 1 tablespoon tomato ketchup , 1 tablespoon soy sauce , 1 teaspoon chili powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon cumin powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn translucent. Add minced garlic, grated ginger, and chopped green chilies. Sauté for another minute until fragrant. Add chopped tomatoes to the pan and cook until they soften and turn mushy. Add mixed vegetables (carrots, bell peppers, beans, corn) to the pan. Stir well to combine with the onion-tomato mixture. Season the vegetables with salt, chili powder, turmeric powder, and cumin powder. Mix everything well. Cover the pan and let the vegetables cook for about 10-12 minutes until they are tender but still have a bite to them. Once the vegetables are cooked, add tomato ketchup and soy sauce to the pan. Mix well to coat the vegetables with the sauces. Cook for another 2-3 minutes until the flavors meld together and the sauce thickens slightly. Remove the pan from heat and transfer the Veg Chilli Milli to a serving dish. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves before serving.

name: Singhare Ki Poori For Ekadasi Vrat
description: During Ekadasi Vrat, when grains are restricted, Singhare Ki Pooris offer a delightful and crispy alternative. These pooris are made with water chestnut flour (singhare ka atta), a naturally gluten-free option. Kneaded into a dough and deep-fried, they puff up into golden spheres that are perfect for enjoying with sabzi or even a simple chutney.
ingredients: 1 cup Singhare (Water Chestnut) flour , 1 medium-sized boiled potato, mashed , 1 green chili, finely chopped (optional) , Sendha namak (Rock salt) to taste , 1 tablespoon chopped coriander leaves , Ghee or oil for frying , Water as needed
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the Singhare flour, mashed potato, green chili, rock salt, and chopped coriander leaves. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. The dough should be firm but pliable. Divide the dough into small portions and roll each portion into a ball. Heat ghee or oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Flatten each ball with your palm and roll it out into a small disc using a rolling pin. Carefully slide the rolled poori into the hot oil and fry until it puffs up and turns golden brown on both sides. Remove the poori from the oil and drain excess oil on paper towels. Serve hot with your favorite vrat ki sabzi or yogurt.

name: Kele Ka Kofta
description: Kele Ka Kofta is a vegetarian delight featuring melt-in-your-mouth potato dumplings bathed in a creamy and flavorful sauce. Imagine soft, pillowy mashed potato balls gently spiced and fried, then immersed in a rich gravy bursting with the taste of tomatoes, onions, and fragrant spices. This dish is a textural and flavorful symphony, perfect for satisfying your savory cravings.
ingredients: 3 ripe bananas , 1 cup gram flour (besan) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Oil for frying , For the gravy: , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 1 onion, chopped , 1-inch piece of ginger, chopped , 3-4 cloves of garlic, chopped , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon garam masala , 1/2 cup fresh cream , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Peel and mash the ripe bananas in a bowl. Add gram flour, chopped onion, green chilies, turmeric powder, cumin seeds, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt to the mashed bananas. Mix well to form a dough. Divide the dough into small portions and shape them into round koftas. Heat oil in a pan and deep fry the koftas until golden brown. Drain and set aside. In another pan, heat some oil and add cumin seeds. Once they splutter, add chopped onions, ginger, and garlic. Saute until onions turn translucent. Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, garam masala, and salt. Cook until tomatoes turn soft and mushy. Allow the mixture to cool slightly, then blend it into a smooth paste using a blender. Return the blended mixture to the pan and add fresh cream. Cook for another 2-3 minutes. Add the fried koftas to the gravy and simmer for 5 minutes. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Rajgira Paratha
description: Rajgira Paratha offers a delightful twist on the classic flatbread. Made with flour derived from finger millet (rajgira), it's a naturally gluten-free option perfect for those with dietary restrictions. The nutty flavor of the flour pairs beautifully with a savory filling, often spiced with turmeric, coriander, and cumin. These parathas are then cooked on a griddle until crisp, providing a delicious and nutritious option for breakfast or a light meal.
ingredients: 1 cup rajgira (amaranth) flour , 1 medium-sized boiled potato, mashed , 2-3 green chilies, finely chopped , 2 tablespoons fresh coriander leaves, chopped , Salt to taste , Water, as needed , Ghee or oil for cooking
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the rajgira flour, mashed potato, chopped green chilies, coriander leaves, and salt. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. Divide the dough into small portions and roll each portion into a ball. Take one ball of dough and flatten it slightly on a clean, dry surface. Using a rolling pin, roll out the dough ball into a thin, round paratha. Heat a tawa or skillet over medium heat and place the rolled-out paratha on it. Cook the paratha for about 1-2 minutes on one side, then flip it over. Spread a little ghee or oil on the cooked side of the paratha and cook for another 1-2 minutes, pressing gently with a spatula, until both sides are golden brown and cooked through. Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions to make more parathas. Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or any side dish of your choice.

name: Gulgule
description: Gulgule are melt-in-your-mouth Indian sweet treats that offer a delightful burst of flavor in every bite. Imagine fluffy, deep-fried dough balls infused with a fragrant cardamom filling. Dipped in a sweet sugar syrup for a touch of glistening decadence, these golden pillows are a perfect way to satisfy your sweet tooth or add a festive touch to celebrations.
ingredients: 1 cup all-purpose flour (maida) , 1/4 cup semolina (sooji) , 1/2 cup sugar , 1/2 teaspoon baking powder , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , A pinch of salt , Water, as needed , Oil, for deep frying
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine all-purpose flour, semolina, sugar, baking powder, cardamom powder, and a pinch of salt. Gradually add water to the dry ingredients and mix well to form a smooth batter. The consistency should be similar to pancake batter. Heat oil in a deep frying pan or kadhai over medium heat. Once the oil is hot, carefully drop spoonfuls of the batter into the oil using a spoon or your fingers. Fry in batches, making sure not to overcrowd the pan. Fry the gulgule until they turn golden brown and crispy on all sides, flipping occasionally for even cooking. This usually takes about 2-3 minutes per batch. Once done, remove the fried gulgule using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on paper towels. Repeat the frying process with the remaining batter. Serve the hot and crispy gulgule as a dessert or snack. They can be enjoyed on their own or with a cup of chai.

name: Instant Pot Pulao
description: Instant Pot Pulao brings the vibrant flavors of Indian rice pilaf to your table in record time. Fragrant basmati rice is layered with aromatic spices, vegetables, and your choice of protein (cashews, peas, lentils, or shredded chicken are all popular options). The magic of the Instant Pot steams everything to perfection, resulting in a fluffy, flavorful rice dish perfect for a quick and satisfying weeknight meal.
ingredients: 1 cup basmati rice , 1 tablespoon oil or ghee , 1 onion, thinly sliced , 1 tomato, chopped , 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans) , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 green chili, slit lengthwise (optional) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 cinnamon stick , 2-3 cloves , 2-3 cardamom pods , 1 bay leaf , 1 teaspoon garam masala , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , 2 cups water , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Rinse the basmati rice under running water until the water runs clear. Soak the rice in water for 15-20 minutes, then drain and set aside. Press the "Saute" button on the Instant Pot. Heat oil or ghee in the pot. Add cumin seeds, cinnamon stick, cloves, cardamom pods, and bay leaf. Saute for a few seconds until fragrant. Add sliced onions and saute until they turn golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and green chili. Saute for another minute. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Add mixed vegetables, garam masala, turmeric powder, and salt. Stir well to combine. Add soaked and drained rice to the pot and mix gently with the vegetables. Pour 2 cups of water into the pot and give it a stir. Close the lid of the Instant Pot and set the valve to the sealing position. Select the "Manual" or "Pressure Cook" mode and set the timer for 5 minutes on high pressure. Once the cooking cycle is complete, allow natural pressure release for 5 minutes, then carefully release the remaining pressure manually. Open the lid and fluff the pulao with a fork. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with yogurt or raita.

name: Bharwa Baingan
description: Bharwa Baingan is a vegetarian showstopper. Eggplant halves are hollowed out and transformed into flavorful little boats. A savory stuffing of spiced lentils, onions, and herbs fills the centers, creating a delightful textural contrast between the soft, melt-in-your-mouth eggplant and the hearty, spiced filling.
ingredients: 8 small eggplants (baingan) , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1 teaspoon cumin powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Wash the eggplants and make a slit in the center without cutting them into two halves. Keep them aside. Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for another minute. Now, add chopped tomatoes and cook until they become soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes. Remove the pan from heat and let the masala mixture cool down. Once cooled, stuff the masala mixture into the slits of the eggplants. Heat oil in a separate pan and place the stuffed eggplants gently. Cook the eggplants on low heat, turning them occasionally, until they become soft and tender. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with roti or rice.

name: Missi Roti
