description: Missi Roti adds a vibrant twist to the classic Indian flatbread. Instead of plain dough, a perky mixture of gram flour (besan) spices, and herbs is kneaded into a soft, pliable base.  This flavorful twist is then cooked on a griddle until speckled with golden brown spots, making it a unique and delicious accompaniment to curries or dals.
ingredients: 1 cup whole wheat flour , 1/2 cup chickpea flour (besan) , 1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro (coriander) , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 1 green chili, finely chopped (optional) , 1/2 teaspoon carom seeds (ajwain) , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon cumin powder , 1/2 teaspoon coriander powder , Salt to taste , Water, as needed , Ghee or oil, for cooking
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour, chickpea flour, chopped cilantro, chopped onion, green chili, carom seeds, turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a soft dough. Let it rest for 15-20 minutes. Divide the dough into equal-sized balls and roll them out into rotis using a rolling pin. Heat a skillet or tawa over medium heat and cook the rotis on both sides, applying ghee or oil until golden brown spots appear. Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls. Serve hot with your favorite curry or yogurt.

name: Lemon Pickle
description: Pucker up for a punch of citrus! Lemon pickle is a tangy condiment bursting with sunshine. Bright yellow lemons are sliced and cured in a vibrant blend of spices, often including mustard seeds, chili flakes, and fenugreek. Over time, the lemons take on a complex flavor profile, offering a delightful sour and spicy counterpoint to any meal.
ingredients: 10-12 medium-sized lemons , 1/4 cup salt , 2 tablespoons mustard seeds , 1 tablespoon fenugreek seeds , 1 tablespoon turmeric powder , 2 tablespoons red chili powder , 1/4 cup mustard oil
instruction: Wash the lemons thoroughly and pat them dry. Cut each lemon into 8 pieces and remove any seeds. In a bowl, mix the lemon pieces with salt and turmeric powder. Let it sit for about 4-6 hours, allowing the lemons to release their juices. Dry roast the mustard seeds and fenugreek seeds separately until fragrant. Grind them into a coarse powder. After the lemons have marinated, heat mustard oil in a pan. Add the ground mustard-fenugreek powder and red chili powder. Cook for a minute until fragrant. Add the marinated lemon pieces to the pan and cook for about 5-7 minutes until the lemon skins become slightly soft. Remove from heat and let the pickle cool down to room temperature. Transfer the pickle into a clean, sterilized glass jar and store it in a cool, dry place. Your homemade lemon pickle is ready to serve! Enjoy it with rice, roti, or any meal of your choice.

name: Cabbage Pakoda
description: Cabbage pakoda is a delightful fritter experience. Imagine shredded cabbage, seasoned with fragrant spices, transformed into a crispy golden bite with a fluffy interior. Chickpea flour batter binds everything together, ensuring a delightful textural contrast in every mouthful. These tasty fritters are perfect for enjoying as a tea-time snack or as an accompaniment to a larger meal.
ingredients: 2 cups shredded cabbage , 1 cup chickpea flour (besan) , 2 tablespoons rice flour , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 2-3 green chilies, finely chopped , 1 teaspoon ginger paste , 1 teaspoon garlic paste , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , Oil for frying , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine the shredded cabbage, chopped onion, green chilies, ginger paste, and garlic paste. Add chickpea flour, rice flour, turmeric powder, cumin seeds, garam masala, and salt to the bowl. Mix well to coat the cabbage evenly with the flour mixture. Gradually add a little water as needed to form a thick batter that coats the cabbage mixture well. Heat oil for frying in a deep pan or kadhai over medium heat. Once the oil is hot, take small portions of the cabbage mixture and drop them gently into the hot oil using your fingers or a spoon. Fry the pakodas in batches, making sure not to overcrowd the pan, until they turn golden brown and crisp. This usually takes about 4-5 minutes per batch. Remove the fried pakodas using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on paper towels. Garnish the cabbage pakodas with fresh cilantro leaves and serve hot with your favorite chutney or sauce.

name: Methi Pakoda
description: Methi Pakoda is a symphony of fresh fenugreek leaves (methi) encased in a light and airy chickpea batter. Imagine vibrant green fenugreek leaves, bursting with flavor, enveloped in a crispy, golden gram flour shell. This delightful vegetarian fritter is perfect for a quick snack or a flavorful tea-time companion.
ingredients: 1 cup fresh fenugreek leaves (methi), washed and finely chopped , 1 cup chickpea flour (besan) , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 2-3 green chilies, finely chopped , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon cumin powder , Salt to taste , Oil for deep frying
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine chopped fenugreek leaves, chickpea flour, chopped onion, green chilies, ginger-garlic paste, turmeric powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, and salt. Mix all the ingredients well to form a thick batter. If the batter is too dry, you can add a little water to adjust the consistency. Heat oil in a deep frying pan or kadhai over medium heat. Once the oil is hot, take small portions of the batter and drop them carefully into the hot oil using a spoon. Fry the pakodas in batches until they turn golden brown and crispy. Make sure not to overcrowd the pan. Once done, remove the fried pakodas using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on a paper towel. Serve hot Methi Pakodas with green chutney or ketchup as a snack or appetizer.

name: Aloo Chole Ki Sabji
description: Aloo Chole Ki Sabji is a hearty and comforting chickpea (chole) curry with potatoes (aloo) in a rich gravy. Imagine tender chickpeas simmered in a flavorful tomato base, studded with fluffy potatoes and seasoned with warming spices. This satisfying vegetarian dish is a complete meal in itself, perfect for scooping up with rice or roti.
ingredients: 2 medium potatoes, peeled and cubed , 1 cup cooked chickpeas (or canned) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, pureed , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch ginger, grated , 1 green chili, chopped (optional) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1 teaspoon garam masala , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown. Add minced garlic, grated ginger, and chopped green chili. Sauté for another minute. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for a minute. Add pureed tomatoes and cook until the oil separates from the masala. Add cubed potatoes and cooked chickpeas. Mix well to coat them with the masala. Add water as needed to achieve the desired consistency of the gravy. Cover and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the potatoes are tender and cooked through. Sprinkle garam masala and garnish with fresh cilantro leaves. Serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Veg Kofta Curry
description: Veg Kofta Curry is a symphony of textures and flavors. Bite-sized vegetable dumplings, simmered in a rich and creamy tomato gravy, offer a delightful contrast. The dumplings, made with mashed vegetables and fragrant spices, burst with flavor in every mouthful. The silky smooth gravy, infused with warming spices, creates a luxurious bed for the koftas. This vegetarian delight is a perfect Main Course, begging to be scooped up with fluffy rice or warm rotis.
ingredients: For Koftas: 2 medium potatoes, boiled and mashed , 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans), finely chopped and boiled , 1/2 cup paneer (Indian cottage cheese), grated , 2 tablespoons besan (gram flour) , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon garam masala , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Oil for frying , For Curry: 2 onions, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, pureed , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon cumin powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , 1/2 cup fresh cream , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Making Koftas: In a large mixing bowl, combine mashed potatoes, mixed vegetables, grated paneer, besan, ginger-garlic paste, garam masala, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well to form a smooth dough-like mixture. Divide the mixture into small portions and shape them into round koftas. Heat oil in a deep pan and fry the koftas until golden brown. Remove and set aside. 2. Making Curry: Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a separate pan. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for another minute. Add tomato puree and cook until the oil separates from the mixture. Stir in turmeric powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt. Cook for 2-3 minutes. Add fresh cream and mix well. Cook for another minute. Add 1 cup of water and bring the curry to a gentle boil. 3. Assembling: Place the fried koftas in the curry and simmer for 5-7 minutes until the koftas absorb the flavors of the curry. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or naan.

name: Kuttu Ka Paratha
description: Kuttu Ka Paratha is a delightful twist on the classic Indian flatbread, perfect for those observing religious fasts where grains like wheat are restricted. Buckwheat flour (kuttu) takes center stage, kneaded into a dough and enlivened with spices. Similar to its wheat counterpart, the dough is layered with ghee or oil for richness and flakiness. Pan-fried until golden brown and fragrant, these special flatbreads are a delicious accompaniment to curries or enjoyed on their own.
ingredients: 1 cup buckwheat flour (kuttu ka atta) , 2 medium-sized boiled potatoes, mashed , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon rock salt (sendha namak) , 1 tablespoon fresh coriander leaves, finely chopped , Water, as needed , Ghee or oil for cooking
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the buckwheat flour, mashed potatoes, chopped green chilies, cumin seeds, rock salt, and fresh coriander leaves. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. The dough should be soft but not sticky. Let it rest for 5 minutes. Divide the dough into equal-sized balls and flatten them slightly with your palms. Heat a tawa or griddle over medium heat. Roll out each ball of dough into a circle of about 6-7 inches in diameter, using a rolling pin and a little dry buckwheat flour for dusting. Place the rolled-out paratha on the hot tawa and cook until small bubbles start to appear on the surface. Flip the paratha and spread a little ghee or oil on the cooked side. Cook until golden brown spots appear on both sides, pressing gently with a spatula to ensure even cooking. Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls. Serve hot Kuttu Ka Paratha with yogurt, green chutney, or any side dish of your choice.

name: Pumpkin Halwa
description: Pumpkin halwa is a comforting Indian dessert that transforms humble pumpkin into a decadent treat. Grated pumpkin is simmered in creamy milk, infused with warm spices like cardamom, and sweetened with sugar. As the mixture thickens, it takes on a rich, glossy texture, offering a delightful contrast to the crunchy nuts that often adorn the top. Perfect for a satisfying sweet ending to a meal.
ingredients: 500g pumpkin, grated , 1 cup milk , 1/2 cup sugar , 2 tablespoons ghee (clarified butter) , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , A handful of chopped nuts (almonds, cashews, pistachios) , Saffron strands (optional, for garnish)
instruction: Heat ghee in a pan and add grated pumpkin. Cook pumpkin on low heat until it becomes soft and mushy, stirring occasionally. Add milk and cook until the mixture thickens. Add sugar and cardamom powder, mix well, and cook until the sugar dissolves completely. In a separate pan, lightly roast the chopped nuts in ghee until golden brown. Add the roasted nuts to the pumpkin mixture and mix well. Cook for another 5-7 minutes until the halwa reaches the desired consistency. Garnish with saffron strands (if using). Serve warm or cold, as desired.

name: Chana Dal Pakora
description: Chana Dal Pakora transforms humble Bengal gram (split chickpea) dal into a delightful fritter experience. The dal is soaked and spiced with a vibrant mix of aromatics, then coated in a chickpea flour batter for a crispy exterior. Deep-fried until golden brown, these flavorful fritters make for a satisfying snack or a delicious appetizer.
ingredients: 1 cup chana dal (split chickpeas), soaked for 4 hours , 1 medium onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 2 tablespoons chopped cilantro (coriander leaves) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , Oil for deep frying
instruction: After soaking the chana dal, drain the water and transfer the dal to a blender or food processor. Grind the soaked dal to a coarse paste without adding water. The texture should be slightly coarse, not too smooth. Transfer the ground dal to a mixing bowl and add chopped onions, green chilies, cilantro, cumin seeds, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well to combine all the ingredients evenly. Heat oil in a deep frying pan or kadai over medium heat. Once the oil is hot, take small portions of the dal mixture and carefully drop them into the hot oil using a spoon or your hands. Fry the pakoras in batches, making sure not to overcrowd the pan, until they turn golden brown and crispy, about 4-5 minutes per batch. Using a slotted spoon, remove the fried pakoras from the oil and drain them on paper towels to remove excess oil. Serve hot with green chutney or tomato ketchup as a delicious snack or appetizer.

name: Paneer Pakora
description: Paneer pakora is a delightful vegetarian fritter that bursts with flavor and texture. Cubes of Indian cottage cheese (paneer) are marinated in a fragrant blend of spices, then dipped in a chickpea flour batter. Deep-fried until golden brown and crispy, the result is a delightful combination of soft, pillowy paneer and a flavorful, crunchy coating. Enjoy these pakoras hot with a tangy chutney for a satisfying snack or appetizer.
ingredients: 250g paneer, cut into cubes , 1 cup chickpea flour (besan) , 2 tablespoons rice flour , 1 teaspoon carom seeds (ajwain) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt, to taste , Water, as needed , Oil, for deep frying , Fresh cilantro leaves, for garnish
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine chickpea flour, rice flour, carom seeds, cumin seeds, red chili powder, turmeric powder, garam masala, and salt. Gradually add water to the dry ingredients to make a thick batter, ensuring there are no lumps. Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Dip each paneer cube into the batter, ensuring it's evenly coated, and gently drop it into the hot oil. Fry the paneer pakoras in batches until they turn golden brown and crispy, about 3-4 minutes per batch. Using a slotted spoon, remove the fried paneer pakoras from the oil and place them on a plate lined with paper towels to drain excess oil. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves and serve hot with green chutney or ketchup.

name: Drumstick
description: Drumsticks, also known as moringa pods, are transformed into a delicious side dish with this recipe. The tender pods are seasoned, coated in a crispy batter, and then fried until golden brown. Each bite offers a delightful contrast between the soft interior and the flavorful crunch of the exterior. This dish pairs beautifully with rice, lentils, or curries.
ingredients: 4-5 drumsticks, cut into 3-inch pieces , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch ginger, grated , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste) , Salt to taste , Chopped coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown. Add minced garlic and grated ginger. Sauté for another minute. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well. Add drumstick pieces to the pan and mix until they are coated with the spices. Pour in 1 cup of water and bring the curry to a boil. Reduce the heat, cover the pan, and let the curry simmer for about 15-20 minutes or until the drumsticks are cooked through and tender. Once done, garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with steamed rice or roti.

name: Malai Kulfi
description: Malai Kulfi is a luxurious Indian ice cream made with rich, creamy milk. Imagine this: full-fat milk is simmered patiently, reducing it down to a thick, fragrant concentrate. Luscious cream or clotted cream (malai) is then added, creating a smooth, intensely milky base. Often flavored with cardamom, nuts, and a hint of rosewater, the mixture is poured into molds and frozen for a dense, decadent treat that's sure to beat the summer heat.
ingredients: 2 cups full-fat milk , 1/2 cup sweetened condensed milk , 1/4 cup powdered sugar , 1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder , 2 tablespoons chopped nuts (such as almonds, pistachios)
instruction: In a heavy-bottomed pan, heat the milk over medium heat until it comes to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and simmer the milk, stirring frequently, until it reduces to half its original volume. This may take about 20-25 minutes. Add the condensed milk, powdered sugar, and cardamom powder to the reduced milk. Mix well until everything is combined. Continue to cook the mixture for another 5 minutes, stirring constantly. Turn off the heat and let the mixture cool completely. Once cooled, stir in the chopped nuts. Pour the mixture into kulfi molds or small cups. Cover the molds/cups with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and insert ice cream sticks in the center of each. Place the molds/cups in the freezer and let the kulfi freeze for at least 6-8 hours, or until solid. Once frozen, remove the kulfi from the molds/cups by running them under warm water for a few seconds. Serve immediately and enjoy!

name: Rose Lassi
description: Beat the summer heat with a refreshing glass of Rose Lassi! This cool and creamy drink blends tangy yogurt with the delicate floral notes of rose. Imagine sweet rose syrup swirled into chilled yogurt, creating a delightful pink beverage. A hint of spice from cardamom (optional) adds another layer of complexity. It's a simple yet captivating beverage perfect for a quick pick-me-up or a delightful ending to a meal.
ingredients: 1 cup plain yogurt , 1/2 cup cold water , 2 tablespoons rose water , 2 tablespoons sugar (adjust to taste) , A few ice cubes , Crushed pistachios or rose petals for garnish (optional)
instruction: In a blender, combine the plain yogurt, cold water, rose water, and sugar. Blend until smooth and creamy. Taste and adjust the sweetness by adding more sugar if needed. Add the ice cubes to the blender and pulse until they are crushed and well incorporated into the lassi. Pour the rose lassi into glasses. Garnish with crushed pistachios or rose petals if desired. Serve immediately and enjoy the refreshing taste of rose lassi!

name: Amchur Powder
description: Amchur powder, also known as dry mango powder, captures the tangy essence of unripe mangoes in a convenient form. To create this vibrant spice, raw mangoes are thinly sliced and patiently sun-dried until their moisture evaporates. The dried bits are then ground into a fine powder, ready to add a burst of citrusy acidity and subtle sweetness to your dishes.
ingredients: 2 medium-sized raw mangoes , Water (as needed)
instruction: Wash the raw mangoes thoroughly and pat them dry. Peel the mangoes and remove the seeds. Slice the mango flesh into thin pieces. Place the mango slices on a clean, dry cloth or tray in a single layer. Allow the mango slices to sun-dry for 3-4 days, turning them occasionally to ensure even drying. Once the mango slices are completely dried and crisp, transfer them to a grinder or blender. Grind the dried mango slices into a fine powder. Store the amchur powder in an airtight container in a cool, dry place.

name: Karachi Halwa
description: Karachi Halwa is a textural delight, offering a creamy and melt-in-your-mouth experience. This sweet treat combines semolina flour with sugar syrup for a base that thickens as it cooks. Ghee is added in stages, enriching the flavor and creating a luxurious sheen. Often flavored with cardamom and a touch of kewra water (or rose water) for a floral note, Karachi Halwa can be enjoyed warm or at room temperature.
ingredients: 1 cup cornflour , 1 cup sugar , 1/2 cup ghee (clarified butter) , 3 cups water , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , A handful of chopped nuts (cashews, almonds, pistachios) , A pinch of saffron strands (optional)
instruction: Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium heat. Add cornflour to the ghee and roast it on low heat until it turns golden brown and releases a nutty aroma. Keep stirring continuously to avoid burning. In another saucepan, combine water and sugar. Bring it to a boil until the sugar dissolves completely. Slowly pour the sugar syrup into the roasted cornflour mixture while stirring continuously to avoid lumps. Cook the mixture on low heat, stirring constantly, until it thickens and starts leaving the sides of the pan. Add cardamom powder and chopped nuts to the mixture. Mix well. Pour the mixture into a greased tray or plate and spread it evenly using a spatula. Garnish with saffron strands if desired. Let the mixture cool for about 1-2 hours until it sets completely. Once set, cut the Karachi Halwa into desired shapes and serve.

name: Urad Dal Kachori
description: Urad Dal Kachori is a delightful explosion of taste and textures. Imagine crispy, golden fried shells made from whole wheat flour dough, filled with a savory and mildly spiced lentil mixture. The richness of the urad dal (black gram) filling contrasts perfectly with the flakiness of the exterior, making it a popular tea-time snack or a delicious accompaniment to a meal.
ingredients: 1 cup urad dal (black gram lentils), soaked for 4 hours , 1 cup all-purpose flour (maida) , 2 tablespoons ghee or oil , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon fennel seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , Oil for deep frying
instruction: Drain the soaked urad dal and grind it into a coarse paste without adding water. Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee or oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and fennel seeds. Saute for a minute. Add the ground urad dal paste to the pan. Cook on low heat, stirring continuously, until the dal turns aromatic and slightly browned. This will take about 10-12 minutes. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt to the cooked dal. Mix well and cook for another 2-3 minutes. Remove from heat and let it cool. In a mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour with the remaining ghee or oil. Mix well until the flour resembles breadcrumbs. Gradually add water and knead into a smooth dough. Cover and let it rest for 15 minutes. Divide the dough into small equal-sized balls. Roll out each ball into a small circle. Place a spoonful of the cooled urad dal mixture in the center of each dough circle. Bring the edges together and seal tightly to form a ball. Heat oil in a deep pan for frying. Once the oil is hot, carefully slide in the stuffed dough balls. Fry the kachoris on medium heat until they turn golden brown and crispy on all sides. Remove from the oil and drain excess oil on paper towels. Serve hot with your favorite chutney or sauce.

name: Broccoli Paratha
description: Broccoli Paratha injects vibrant greens and a delightful textural contrast into the classic flatbread. Finely chopped broccoli florets are incorporated into whole wheat dough, adding a subtle veggie flavor and a satisfying crunch. Like its close cousin the Ajwain Paratha, the dough is layered with ghee or oil, creating flaky layers that turn golden brown and crisp when cooked on a griddle. Enjoyed plain or dipped in chutney, Broccoli Paratha is a delightful vegetarian option for breakfast or a light meal.
ingredients: 1 cup finely chopped broccoli , 2 cups whole wheat flour , 1 tablespoon oil , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon grated ginger , 1 green chili, finely chopped , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Water, as needed , Ghee or oil for cooking
instruction: Steam the chopped broccoli until it's tender. Drain any excess water and let it cool. In a mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour, cooked broccoli, grated ginger, green chili, turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin seeds, oil, and salt. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. Let it rest for 15-20 minutes. Divide the dough into equal-sized balls and roll each ball into a flat circle, dusting with flour as needed. Heat a griddle or tawa over medium heat. Place a rolled paratha on the griddle and cook until bubbles appear on the surface. Flip the paratha and drizzle some ghee or oil around the edges. Press gently with a spatula and cook until both sides are golden brown. Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls. Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or any chutney of your choice.

name: Lauki Ki Kheer
description: Lauki Ki Kheer offers a delightful twist on the classic Indian rice pudding.  Imagine grated bottle gourd (lauki) simmered in creamy milk, infused with fragrant cardamom and pistachios. This unique dessert is surprisingly light yet satisfying, perfect for those seeking a flavorful and healthy sweet treat.
ingredients: 1 cup grated bottle gourd (lauki) , 4 cups milk , 1/2 cup sugar (adjust according to taste) , 1/4 cup rice , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , 2 tablespoons chopped nuts (almonds, pistachios, cashews) , Saffron strands (optional) , 1 tablespoon ghee (clarified butter)
instruction: Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan and add grated bottle gourd. Saute for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft. Add rice to the pan and roast for a few minutes. Pour milk into the pan and let it come to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and let the kheer simmer, stirring occasionally, until the rice and bottle gourd are cooked and the mixture thickens. This will take about 20-25 minutes. Once the kheer thickens, add sugar, cardamom powder, chopped nuts, and saffron strands (if using). Mix well and cook for another 5 minutes. Remove from heat and let the kheer cool to room temperature. Serve Lauki Ki Kheer chilled or warm, garnished with more chopped nuts if desired.

name: Beetroot Paratha
description: Brighten your mornings with Beetroot Paratha, a vibrant twist on the classic flatbread. Tender, shredded beetroot adds pops of color and subtle sweetness to whole wheat dough. The dough is then layered with ghee or oil, creating flaky layers that turn golden brown and crisp when cooked on a griddle. Enjoy these delightful parcels as part of a hearty breakfast or a flavorful lunch.
ingredients: 2 cups whole wheat flour , 1 cup grated beetroot , 1 green chili, finely chopped (optional) , 1 teaspoon ginger paste , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Water, as needed , Ghee or butter for cookinga
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine whole wheat flour, grated beetroot, green chili (if using), ginger paste, cumin seeds, turmeric powder, red chili powder, salt, and 1 tablespoon oil. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. Add water as needed to achieve the right consistency. Divide the dough into equal-sized balls and flatten them slightly. Dust each dough ball with flour and roll it out into a circle using a rolling pin. Heat a skillet or tawa over medium heat. Place a rolled-out paratha on the skillet. Cook until small bubbles start to appear on the surface, then flip the paratha. Spread a little ghee or butter on the cooked side, then flip again and spread ghee or butter on the other side. Cook until both sides are golden brown and crispy. Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls. Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or any side dish of your choice.

name: Aloo Chana Chaat
description: Aloo Chana Chaat is a burst of tangy, savory, and spicy flavors in a vibrant street food salad. Imagine fluffy boiled potatoes and nutty chickpeas tossed together with a medley of chopped onions, tomatoes, and cilantro. A squeeze of lemon juice adds a delightful tang, while a sprinkle of chaat masala elevates the entire dish with its aromatic and citrusy notes. Each bite is a textural and flavorful adventure, perfect as a light lunch, satisfying snack, or a side to complement your meal.
ingredients: 2 cups boiled chickpeas (chana) , 2 large potatoes, boiled and diced , 1 onion, finely chopped , 1 tomato, finely chopped , 1 green chili, finely chopped , 2 tablespoons fresh coriander leaves, chopped , 1 tablespoon tamarind chutney , 1 tablespoon mint chutney , 1 teaspoon chaat masala , 1 teaspoon roasted cumin powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Lemon wedges for garnish , Sev (crunchy chickpea noodles) for garnish (optional)
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine the boiled chickpeas, diced potatoes, chopped onion, tomato, green chili, and coriander leaves. Add tamarind chutney, mint chutney, chaat masala, roasted cumin powder, red chili powder, and salt to taste. Mix well until all ingredients are evenly coated. Taste and adjust seasoning if needed. Transfer the chaat to serving plates or bowls. Garnish with lemon wedges and sev (if using). Serve immediately and enjoy your delicious Aloo Chana Chaat!

name: Biryani Masala
description: Biryani masala is the aromatic heart of any biryani dish. This warm spice blend is a symphony of flavors, created by toasting and grinding a vibrant collection of whole spices. Fragrant cardamom, earthy cumin, fiery chilies, and a touch of floral mace come together to create a complex and irresistible perfume. This essential ingredient adds depth and character to any biryani, taking your rice dish from ordinary to extraordinary.
ingredients: 2 tablespoons coriander seeds , 1 tablespoon cumin seeds , 1 tablespoon black peppercorns , 1 tablespoon fennel seeds , 1 tablespoon cloves , 1 tablespoon cardamom pods , 1 cinnamon stick , 1 teaspoon nutmeg powder , 1 teaspoon mace powder , 2 dried bay leaves , 4 dried red chilies , 1 tablespoon turmeric powder , 1 tablespoon red chili powder , Salt to taste
instruction: Dry roast coriander seeds, cumin seeds, black peppercorns, fennel seeds, cloves, cardamom pods, cinnamon stick, dried bay leaves, and dried red chilies in a pan until fragrant. Let the roasted spices cool down, then grind them into a fine powder using a spice grinder or mortar and pestle. Transfer the ground spices to a bowl and mix in turmeric powder, red chili powder, nutmeg powder, and mace powder. Store the biryani masala in an airtight container in a cool, dry place for up to 2 months.

name: Kashmiri Biryani
description: Kashmiri Biryani is a symphony of flavors and textures. Fluffy basmati rice is infused with aromatic spices like cardamom and saffron, creating a warm, fragrant base. Tender pieces of meat (traditionally lamb) are nestled amongst the rice, while slivered almonds and dried fruits add pops of sweetness and textural contrast. Each bite is a delightful journey through the unique culinary landscape of Kashmir.
ingredients: 2 cups basmati rice , 1 onion, thinly sliced , 1 tomato, chopped , 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, potatoes) , 1/2 cup yogurt , 1/4 cup cashews, almonds, and raisins , 2 tablespoons ghee or vegetable oil , 1 cinnamon stick , 4 green cardamom pods , 4 cloves , 1 bay leaf , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon Kashmiri red chili powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon saffron strands (optional) , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Rinse the basmati rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Soak the rice in water for 30 minutes, then drain and set aside. In a large pan or pot, heat the ghee or vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the cinnamon stick, cardamom pods, cloves, bay leaf, and cumin seeds. Fry for 1-2 minutes until fragrant. Add the sliced onion to the pan and sauté until golden brown. Stir in the ginger-garlic paste and cook for another 1-2 minutes. Add the chopped tomato, mixed vegetables, Kashmiri red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Cook for 5-7 minutes until the vegetables are partially cooked. In a separate bowl, whisk the yogurt until smooth. Add the yogurt to the pan and mix well with the vegetable mixture. Add the soaked and drained basmati rice to the pan. Pour enough water to cover the rice by about 1 inch. Cover the pan with a lid and cook the biryani on low heat for 15-20 minutes, or until the rice is cooked and the liquid is absorbed. While the biryani is cooking, dry roast the cashews, almonds, and raisins in a separate pan until golden brown. Set aside. Once the biryani is cooked, fluff the rice gently with a fork. Sprinkle the saffron strands (if using) over the rice and cover the pan. Let it sit for 5 minutes to allow the flavors to meld. Garnish the biryani with the roasted nuts and dried fruits, and fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with raita or yogurt on the side.

name: Aloo Paneer
description: Aloo Paneer is a vegetarian delight that combines the heartiness of potatoes (aloo) with the creamy richness of paneer (Indian cottage cheese). Imagine tender cubes of paneer and fluffy potatoes simmered in a fragrant tomato gravy bursting with warming spices. This comforting dish is a perfect Main Course, ideal for scooping up with fluffy rice or soft rotis.
ingredients: 200g paneer, cubed , 2 large potatoes, peeled and diced , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, pureed , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and green chilies. Sauté until onions turn golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute. Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates from the masala. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well. Add diced potatoes and cook until they are partially done. Add cubed paneer and mix gently with the masala. Cover and cook on low heat until potatoes are tender and paneer is soft. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with roti or rice.

name: Dalia
description: Dalia, a dish made with broken wheat, is a nourishing and versatile breakfast option. The cracked wheat is cooked with water or milk until it reaches a porridge-like consistency. Dalia's beauty lies in its simplicity - it can be enjoyed plain or dressed up with nuts, raisins, chopped vegetables, or a drizzle of honey for a touch of sweetness. This fiber-rich breakfast keeps you feeling satisfied throughout the morning.
ingredients: 1 cup cracked wheat (Dalia) , 2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans, capsicum) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 1-inch ginger, grated , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , 2 cups water , 1 tablespoon oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pressure cooker or deep pan. Add cumin seeds and mustard seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions, green chilies, ginger, and garlic. Saute until onions turn translucent. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they become soft and mushy. Add mixed vegetables and cook for a few minutes. Rinse the cracked wheat (Dalia) thoroughly and add it to the vegetables. Stir in turmeric powder, coriander powder, garam masala, and salt. Add water and mix well. Close the pressure cooker lid or cover the pan with a lid. Cook for 2 whistles in the pressure cooker or simmer for about 15-20 minutes until the Dalia and vegetables are cooked through. Once done, let the pressure release naturally. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot and enjoy the nutritious Vegetable Dalia!

name: Oats Khichdi
description: Oats Khichdi offers a comforting twist on the classic Indian dish. Imagine a warm and hearty bowl combining the goodness of oats with protein-rich lentils. This nutritious meal gets a flavor boost from fragrant spices and a vibrant mix of chopped vegetables. It's a quick and easy one-pot wonder, perfect for a satisfying and wholesome vegetarian meal.
ingredients: 1 cup rolled oats , 1/2 cup yellow moong dal (split yellow lentils) , 2 cups water , 1 onion, finely chopped , 1 tomato, finely chopped , 1 green chili, finely chopped , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 tablespoon ghee or oil , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Rinse the moong dal thoroughly and soak it in water for 15 minutes. Heat ghee or oil in a pressure cooker. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add chopped onions, green chilies, and ginger-garlic paste. Saute until onions turn translucent. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Drain the water from soaked moong dal and add it to the cooker along with rolled oats. Add turmeric powder and salt. Mix well. Pour 2 cups of water and stir to combine all ingredients. Close the pressure cooker lid and cook on medium flame for 2 whistles. Once the pressure releases naturally, open the lid and give the khichdi a gentle mix. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or any side of your choice.

name: Kovakkai Fry
description: Kovakkai Fry is a vibrant South Indian dish bursting with flavor and texture. Tender baby eggplants (kovalkkai) are stir-fried until crisp-tender, absorbing a fragrant blend of warming spices. The addition of shredded coconut adds a touch of sweetness and textural contrast, making this dish a delightful accompaniment to rice or sambar.
ingredients: 250g Kovakkai (Ivy Gourd), sliced , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 2-3 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter. Add cumin seeds and sauté for a few seconds. Add chopped onions and green chilies. Sauté until onions turn translucent. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well. Add sliced Kovakkai (Ivy Gourd) and stir to combine. Cover and cook on low heat until Kovakkai is tender, stirring occasionally. Once Kovakkai is cooked, remove the lid and fry for a few more minutes until it becomes slightly crispy. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Balushahi
description: Balushai is a sweet treat that marries contrasting textures. Imagine bite-sized balls of dough, deep-fried until golden and crisp on the outside. Dipped in a fragrant sugar syrup, the insides soften to reveal a delightful flakiness. This indulgent Indian dessert offers a burst of sweetness in every bite, perfect for satisfying your sweet tooth or celebrating special occasions.
ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour , 1/2 cup yogurt , 1/4 cup ghee (clarified butter) , 1/2 teaspoon baking powder , 1/4 teaspoon baking soda , 1 cup sugar , 1/2 cup water , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , Saffron strands for garnish (optional) , Oil for deep frying
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, baking powder, and baking soda. Add the ghee to the flour mixture and rub it in until it resembles breadcrumbs. Gradually add yogurt and knead into a stiff dough. Cover and let it rest for 30 minutes. After resting, divide the dough into equal-sized portions and shape them into small discs with a hole in the center. Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Fry the Balushahi in batches until golden brown and crispy. Remove from oil and drain excess oil on paper towels. In a separate saucepan, combine sugar, water, and cardamom powder. Cook until the sugar dissolves and the syrup thickens slightly. Dip the fried Balushahi into the sugar syrup, ensuring they are coated evenly. Allow the Balushahi to soak in the syrup for a few minutes, then remove and place them on a serving plate. Garnish with saffron strands if desired. Let them cool completely before serving.

name: Mogri Ki Sabji
description: Mogri Ki Sabji is a comforting dish made with sprouted mogri (pearl millet). The tiny, protein-packed pearls of mogri are sprouted to enhance their nutritional value. These crunchy sprouts are then stir-fried with fragrant spices, onions, and sometimes even chopped vegetables, creating a flavorful and healthy sabji. This simple dish is a delightful addition to any vegetarian meal, perfect for scooping up with rice or roti.
ingredients: 250g fresh mogri (Indian cluster beans) , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2-3 green chilies, finely chopped , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Rinse the mogri under cold water and drain well. Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add chopped green chilies and ginger-garlic paste. Saute for a minute. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, and red chili powder. Mix well. Add the drained mogri to the pan. Stir to coat the mogri with the spices. Cover and cook for 8-10 minutes or until the mogri is tender, stirring occasionally. Once the mogri is cooked, remove the lid and let any excess moisture evaporate. Season with salt according to taste and mix well. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves before serving.

name: Tomato Shorba
description: Tomato Shorba is a comforting and flavorful Indian soup, perfect for a light meal or appetizer. Ripe tomatoes are simmered with warming spices like cumin, coriander, and sometimes a touch of chili, creating a base both tangy and slightly sweet. Fresh cilantro adds a final burst of brightness, making this a delightful way to enjoy the essence of tomatoes.
ingredients: 4 large tomatoes, chopped , 1 onion, chopped , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch piece of ginger, grated , 2 cups vegetable broth , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste) , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon olive oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until translucent. Add minced garlic and grated ginger. Sauté for another minute. Add chopped tomatoes to the pot and cook until they soften and release their juices. Stir in coriander powder, turmeric powder, and red chili powder. Cook for 2-3 minutes. Pour in vegetable broth and season with salt. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat and let it simmer for 10-15 minutes. Once the flavors have melded and the soup has slightly thickened, remove from heat. Use an immersion blender or transfer the mixture to a blender and blend until smooth. Return the soup to the pot and reheat if necessary. Serve hot, garnished with fresh coriander leaves.

name: Thandai
description: Thandai, a refreshing beverage perfect for hot days, is a symphony of cool and creamy goodness. Nuts, seeds, and fragrant spices like cardamom and fennel seeds are soaked and ground into a paste. This fragrant base is then mixed with chilled milk, sugar, and a touch of rose water for a beautiful pink hue. Enjoy this delightful drink topped with chopped nuts and a sprinkle of rose petals for a truly immersive experience.
ingredients: 1/2 cup almonds, blanched , 1/4 cup cashews, soaked , 2 tablespoons poppy seeds , 2 tablespoons melon seeds , 1 tablespoon fennel seeds , 1 tablespoon whole black peppercorns , 1 tablespoon green cardamom pods , 1 tablespoon rose petals (dried or fresh) , 1/4 cup sugar, or to taste , 4 cups milk , A few saffron strands (optional) , Ice cubes, for serving
instruction: In a blender, combine blanched almonds, soaked cashews, poppy seeds, melon seeds, fennel seeds, black peppercorns, cardamom pods, and rose petals. Grind into a fine paste. Transfer the paste into a bowl, add sugar, and mix well until the sugar dissolves. In a separate saucepan, heat milk over medium heat until it comes to a gentle boil. Add the ground paste to the hot milk and stir well. Let it simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally. Remove from heat and let the mixture cool to room temperature. Strain the mixture through a fine mesh sieve or cheesecloth to remove any coarse particles. Chill the Thandai mixture in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours. Before serving, garnish with saffron strands (if using) and serve Thandai chilled over ice cubes.

name: Mirchi Pakoda
description: Mirchi Pakoda is a symphony of spice and texture in a vegetarian fritter. Imagine plump green chilies, cloaked in a gram flour batter spiked with fragrant spices, then deep-fried until golden brown and crispy. Each bite bursts with heat, balanced by the chickpea flour's savory earthiness. Enjoy these fritters on their own as a delightful snack, or pair them with chutney for an extra flavor punch.
ingredients: 6 large green chilies (such as jalapenos or banana peppers) , 1 cup gram flour (besan) , 2 tablespoons rice flour , 1 teaspoon carom seeds (ajwain) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste) , 1 teaspoon chaat masala , Salt to taste , Water, as needed , Oil for deep frying
instruction: Wash and slit the green chilies lengthwise, removing the seeds if you prefer less heat. Set aside. In a mixing bowl, combine gram flour, rice flour, carom seeds, cumin seeds, turmeric powder, red chili powder, chaat masala, and salt. Gradually add water to the dry ingredients to make a thick batter. The consistency should be such that it coats the back of a spoon. Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Dip each green chili into the batter, ensuring it is coated evenly. Carefully slide the coated chilies into the hot oil, frying in batches as needed. Fry the pakodas until they turn golden brown and crispy, turning occasionally for even frying. Once done, remove the pakodas from the oil and drain excess oil on paper towels. Serve hot with mint chutney or sauce of your choice.

name: Masala Papad
description: Masala Papad is a symphony of textures and spices in a delightful appetizer. Thin lentil wafers (papad) are transformed into a vibrant treat. A fragrant blend of spices and herbs is layered onto the papad, creating a delightful contrast between the crisp base and the flavorful masala topping.
ingredients: 4 Papads (any variety) , 1 small Onion, finely chopped , 1 small Tomato, finely chopped , 1 Green Chili, finely chopped , 2 tablespoons Coriander Leaves, chopped , 1/2 teaspoon Chaat Masala , 1/4 teaspoon Red Chili Powder , Salt to taste , Lemon juice for garnish
instruction: Roast the papads individually over an open flame or in a microwave until they become crisp. Be careful not to burn them. Once roasted, set aside the papads to cool down. In a bowl, mix together the chopped onion, tomato, green chili, and coriander leaves. Add chaat masala, red chili powder, and salt to taste to the vegetable mixture. Mix well. Place the roasted papads on serving plates. Spread the prepared vegetable mixture evenly over each papad. Drizzle some lemon juice over the masala-topped papads. Serve immediately as a crunchy and flavorful appetizer.

name: Gur Ki Roti
description: Gur Ki Roti offers a sweet and comforting twist on the classic Indian flatbread. Imagine whole wheat dough infused with the rich caramel notes of jaggery (gur). Rolled out thin and cooked on a griddle, the roti develops a delightful char while the gur melts into pockets of gooey sweetness. Perfect for a satisfying breakfast or a sweet after-meal treat.
ingredients: 1 cup whole wheat flour , 1/2 cup grated jaggery (gur) , Water (as needed for kneading) , Ghee (clarified butter) for cooking
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour and grated jaggery. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a smooth dough. The dough should be firm but pliable. Divide the dough into equal-sized portions and roll each portion into a ball. Flatten each ball into a small disc using your hands or a rolling pin. Heat a griddle or tawa over medium heat and grease it lightly with ghee. Place a flattened dough disc on the heated griddle and cook until golden brown spots appear on one side. Flip the roti and cook the other side until golden brown spots appear. Remove the cooked roti from the griddle and repeat the process with the remaining dough portions. Serve hot Gur Ki Roti with a dollop of ghee or as desired.

name: Matar Ka Nimona
description: Matar Ka Nimona is a comforting and flavorful dish perfect for a cozy meal. Imagine plump green peas simmered in a rich and creamy tomato gravy, gently spiced with warming notes. The creamy gravy beautifully coats fluffy rice, creating a delightful textural contrast in every bite. This vegetarian dish is a quick and easy option to satisfy your taste buds.
ingredients: 2 cups fresh green peas , 2 medium-sized potatoes, peeled and diced , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1-inch piece of ginger, grated , 3-4 cloves of garlic, minced , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons vegetable oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat vegetable oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn translucent. Add grated ginger and minced garlic. Sauté for another minute. Add chopped tomatoes and slit green chilies. Cook until tomatoes turn soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes. Add diced potatoes and green peas. Stir to coat the vegetables with the masala. Add 1-2 cups of water, depending on the desired consistency of the gravy. Cover the pan and let the mixture simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the potatoes and peas are cooked through. Once cooked, mash a few potatoes with the back of a spoon to thicken the gravy. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with rice or Indian bread.

name: Green Pulao
description: Imagine fluffy rice bursting with fresh flavor - that's Green Pulao! Vibrant green coriander and mint chutney are folded into the rice, along with peas or other green veggies for a delightful pop of color. Each bite is an explosion of fresh herbs and warm spices, making this vegetarian dish a perfect side or light lunch.
ingredients: 1 cup basmati rice, washed and soaked for 30 minutes , 1 cup mixed green herbs (such as coriander, mint, and spinach) , 1 onion, thinly sliced , 2 green chilies, chopped , 1-inch piece of ginger, grated , 3-4 cloves garlic, minced , 1/2 cup green peas , 1/4 cup cashews, toasted , 2 tablespoons ghee or oil , Whole spices (1 bay leaf, 4-5 peppercorns, 2-3 cloves, 1-inch cinnamon stick) , Salt to taste , Water as needed
instruction: In a blender, combine the mixed green herbs, green chilies, ginger, and garlic. Blend into a smooth paste with a little water if needed. Heat ghee or oil in a large pot or pressure cooker. Add the whole spices and sauté until fragrant. Add the sliced onions and sauté until golden brown. Pour in the green herb paste and cook for 2-3 minutes until the raw smell disappears. Add the soaked basmati rice and green peas. Stir well to coat the rice evenly with the herb mixture. Add salt to taste and toast the rice for 2-3 minutes. Pour in enough water (usually 2 cups for 1 cup of rice) and bring to a boil. If using a pressure cooker, close the lid and cook for 1 whistle on medium heat. For regular cooking, cover the pot with a lid and cook on low heat until the rice is tender and water is absorbed, about 15-20 minutes. Once cooked, fluff the rice with a fork and garnish with toasted cashews. Serve hot with raita or any curry of your choice.

name: Cheese Naan
description: Picture this: soft, pillowy flatbread flecked with char from the griddle, enveloping a melty, gooey cheese center. That's the magic of Cheese Naan. Simple dough, flavored with yogurt and a hint of sweetness, is stuffed with your favorite cheese (mozzarella for the classic experience!) and cooked until puffed and irresistible. Enjoy it as a side for dipping in curries or savor it on its own for a delightful cheesy treat.
ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour , 1 teaspoon baking powder , 1/2 teaspoon salt , 1/2 cup plain yogurt , 2 tablespoons melted butter or ghee , 1/2 cup shredded mozzarella cheese (or any cheese of your choice) , 2 tablespoons chopped fresh coriander (cilantro) leaves , Butter or ghee for brushing
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, baking powder, and salt. Add the plain yogurt and melted butter/ghee to the dry ingredients. Mix well to form a soft dough. If the dough is too dry, you can add a little water. Knead the dough on a lightly floured surface for about 5-7 minutes until it becomes smooth and elastic. Cover the dough with a clean cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes. After the resting time, divide the dough into 4 equal portions and roll each portion into a ball. Flatten each ball with your hands and place a tablespoon of shredded cheese and a sprinkle of chopped coriander in the center. Fold the edges of the dough over the filling to seal it and gently roll it out into a circle or oval shape, about 1/4 inch thick. Heat a skillet or tawa over medium heat and place the rolled naan on it. Cook for about 2 minutes until bubbles start to appear on the surface. Flip the naan and cook for another 1-2 minutes until golden brown spots appear on both sides. Brush the cooked naan with butter or ghee before serving. Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions. Serve the cheese naan hot with your favorite curry or chutney.

name: Mango Phirni
description: Creamy rice pudding meets the sunshine in Mango Phirni. This delightful dessert features silky smooth rice cooked in milk, infused with the sweet and tangy essence of ripe mangoes. Cardamom adds a touch of warmth, making each spoonful a luxurious treat. Perfect for a chilled and refreshing end to a meal, Mango Phirni is a celebration of summer in every bite.
ingredients: 1/2 cup Basmati rice , 1 liter milk , 1 cup ripe mango pulp , 1/2 cup sugar (adjust to taste) , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , Saffron strands (for garnish) , Chopped nuts (almonds, pistachios) for garnish
instruction: Rinse the Basmati rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes. After soaking, drain the rice and grind it into a coarse powder. In a heavy-bottomed pan, heat the milk over medium heat until it comes to a boil. Add the ground rice to the boiling milk, stirring continuously to prevent lumps from forming. Cook the mixture on low heat, stirring frequently, until the rice is fully cooked and the mixture thickens to a creamy consistency (approximately 20-25 minutes). Add the sugar and cardamom powder, and mix well until the sugar is dissolved. Remove the pan from the heat and allow the mixture to cool slightly. Once cooled, stir in the mango pulp until well combined. Pour the Mango Phirni into serving bowls or glasses and refrigerate for at least 2 hours to chill. Before serving, garnish with saffron strands and chopped nuts. Serve chilled and enjoy the delightful Mango Phirni!

name: Sweet Paratha
description: Imagine a warm, flaky flatbread filled with the sweet satisfaction of caramelized sugar. That's the essence of a Sweet Paratha. Whole wheat dough is transformed into a canvas for melted ghee and a sprinkle of sugar. The magic happens during cooking, where the sugar transforms into a delightful, caramelized surprise within the crispy layers. Enjoyed warm, it's a delightful treat for breakfast or a sweet snack.
ingredients: 2 cups whole wheat flour , 1/2 cup grated jaggery or brown sugar , 1/4 cup chopped nuts (almonds, cashews, pistachios) , 1/4 teaspoon ground cardamom , 2 tablespoons ghee (clarified butter) , Water, as needed , Ghee or oil, for cooking
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour, grated jaggery or brown sugar, chopped nuts, ground cardamom, and ghee. Slowly add water and knead the mixture into a soft dough. Cover and let it rest for 15-20 minutes. Divide the dough into equal-sized portions and roll each portion into a ball. Take one dough ball and flatten it with a rolling pin to form a small disc. Heat a skillet or tawa over medium heat and lightly grease it with ghee or oil. Place the rolled dough disc on the skillet and cook until golden brown spots appear on one side. Flip the paratha and cook the other side until golden brown spots appear and the paratha is cooked through. Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls. Serve hot Sweet Parathas with yogurt, pickle, or any chutney of your choice.

name: Rose Milkshake
description: Indulge in a taste of springtime with a Rose Milkshake. Imagine chilled milk swirled with the delicate sweetness of rose syrup, creating a refreshingly floral drink. For an extra touch of luxury, a scoop of vanilla ice cream can be added, transforming it into a creamy and delightful treat.
ingredients: 2 cups chilled milk , 3 tablespoons rose syrup , 2 tablespoons sugar (adjust to taste) , 1/4 teaspoon rose water , 1 cup vanilla ice cream , Crushed ice (optional) , Rose petals for garnish (optional)
instruction: In a blender, combine chilled milk, rose syrup, sugar, and rose water. Add vanilla ice cream to the blender. Blend until smooth and creamy. If desired, add crushed ice to adjust the consistency. Pour the milkshake into glasses. Garnish with rose petals. Serve immediately and enjoy the refreshing taste of Rose Milkshake!

name: Arbi Fry
description: Deep fried taro root pieces are transformed into a crispy delight in Arbi Fry. The earthy flavor of arbi is perfectly complemented by a warm spice blend, creating a flavorful contrast. This dish can be enjoyed on its own as a snack or as a side complementing a richer curry.
ingredients: 500g arbi (taro root), peeled and sliced , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish (optional)
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add the sliced arbi to the pan and sauté for 5 minutes. Reduce the heat to low and cover the pan. Let the arbi cook for 10-15 minutes until tender, stirring occasionally. Once the arbi is cooked through, remove the lid and increase the heat to medium-high. Add coriander powder, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt to the pan. Mix well to coat the arbi evenly with the spices. Cook for an additional 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the arbi turns crispy and golden brown. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves if desired. Serve hot as a delicious side dish or snack.

name: Samvat Rice Khichdi
description: Samvat Rice Khichdi offers a comforting and nutritious twist on the classic Indian dish. Tiny, protein-rich Samvat rice, also known as barnyard millet, takes center stage.  It's simmered with vegetables like potatoes and fragrant spices like cumin and coriander, resulting in a creamy, porridge-like consistency. Perfect for a light lunch, this vegetarian dish is both delicious and kind to your digestive system.
ingredients: 1 cup Samvat rice (barnyard millet) , 1/2 cup split yellow mung beans (moong dal) , 2 cups water , 1 tablespoon ghee (clarified butter) or oil , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon grated ginger , 1 green chili, finely chopped (optional) , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Rinse the samvat rice and moong dal under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain well and set aside. In a pressure cooker or a large saucepan, heat the ghee or oil over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add the grated ginger and chopped green chili (if using), and sauté for a minute. Add the drained rice and moong dal to the cooker or saucepan. Stir well to coat the grains with the spices. Pour in the water, add turmeric powder, and season with salt to taste. If using a pressure cooker, close the lid and cook on high pressure for 3 whistles. Then, reduce the heat to low and simmer for another 5 minutes before turning off the heat. If using a saucepan, cover and cook until the rice and dal are soft and fully cooked, stirring occasionally. Once cooked, let the pressure release naturally from the pressure cooker before opening the lid. Fluff the khichdi with a fork and garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or any side of your choice.

name: Bajre Ki Khichdi
description: Bajre Ki Khichdi is a wholesome and comforting dish made with pearl millet (bajra) and lentils. Imagine a rustic porridge where protein-rich lentils are simmered with pearl millet, creating a hearty and nourishing meal. This simple dish is perfect for a light lunch or a comforting dinner, and its health benefits make it a popular choice for those seeking a nutritious option.
ingredients: 1 cup pearl millet (bajra) , 1/2 cup split green gram (moong dal) , 2 tablespoons ghee (clarified butter) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , Water as needed , Fresh cilantro leaves, chopped (for garnish)
instruction: Rinse the pearl millet and split green gram thoroughly under running water. Drain well. Heat ghee in a pressure cooker over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add the rinsed pearl millet and split green gram to the pressure cooker. Stir well. Add turmeric powder and salt to taste. Mix everything together. Pour in water (approximately 4 cups) and stir to combine. Close the pressure cooker with its lid and cook on high heat until the first whistle. Then, reduce the heat to low and cook for another 15 minutes. Turn off the heat and let the pressure release naturally. Once the pressure is released, open the pressure cooker carefully and give the khichdi a gentle stir. Serve hot, garnished with freshly chopped cilantro leaves.

name: Spinach Wraps
description: Picture this: Fresh spinach wraps transform into portable pockets of health. Tender leaves become filled with creamy ricotta cheese, sun-dried tomatoes for a burst of tang, and a sprinkle of herbs for an aromatic touch. They're perfect for a quick lunch or a delightful appetizer, offering a delicious and satisfying bite.
ingredients: 2 cups fresh spinach leaves , 1 cup chickpea flour , 1/2 cup water , 1/4 teaspoon salt , 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder , 1/4 teaspoon onion powder , 1/4 teaspoon paprika , 1 tablespoon olive oil , Sliced vegetables of your choice (e.g., cucumber, bell peppers, carrots) , Hummus or tahini for spreading , Whole wheat wraps
instruction: In a blender or food processor, blend the fresh spinach leaves with water until smooth. In a mixing bowl, combine the chickpea flour, spinach puree, salt, garlic powder, onion powder, and paprika. Mix until well combined and forms a smooth batter. Heat olive oil in a non-stick skillet over medium heat. Pour a ladleful of the batter onto the skillet and spread it out thinly to form a round wrap. Cook for 2-3 minutes on each side until lightly golden brown and cooked through. Repeat with the remaining batter to make additional wraps. To assemble the wraps, spread a layer of hummus or tahini onto each wrap, then add sliced vegetables of your choice. Roll up the wraps tightly and slice in half if desired. Serve immediately or wrap in foil for later.

name: Sabudana Pakoda
description: Sabudana Pakoda is a symphony of textures in a delightful fritter. Tiny tapioca pearls (sabudana) are soaked and blended with a touch of potato for body. The mixture is spiced and then transformed into bite-sized morsels that are deep-fried until golden brown. Each crispy pakoda offers a delightful burst of chewy tapioca contrasted by soft potato, all coming together in a flavorful and satisfying snack.
ingredients: 1 cup sabudana (tapioca pearls) , 2 medium-sized potatoes, boiled and mashed , 1/2 cup roasted peanuts, crushed , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 2 tablespoons coriander leaves, chopped , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , Salt to taste , Oil for frying
instruction: Rinse the sabudana under running water until the water runs clear. Soak the sabudana in enough water to cover them completely for about 4-5 hours or overnight. After soaking, drain any excess water from the sabudana using a strainer. In a large mixing bowl, combine the drained sabudana, mashed potatoes, crushed peanuts, chopped green chilies, coriander leaves, cumin seeds, and salt. Mix well to form a thick batter. Heat oil in a deep frying pan or kadhai over medium heat. Take a small portion of the batter and shape it into small round pakodas or fritters. Carefully drop the pakodas into the hot oil and fry them in batches until they turn golden brown and crispy on all sides. Make sure not to overcrowd the pan. Once done, remove the fried pakodas using a slotted spoon and drain them on paper towels to remove excess oil. Serve the hot and crispy Sabudana Pakodas with green chutney or ketchup.

name: Aloo Chokha
description: Aloo Chokha is a simple yet comforting mashed potato dish, bursting with rustic charm. Boiled potatoes are mashed together with onions, chilies, and a touch of lemon juice, creating a vibrant medley of textures. This quick and easy dish is a delightful side to pair with rotis or phulka for a wholesome and satisfying meal.
ingredients: 4 medium-sized potatoes, 2 medium-sized tomatoes, finely chopped, 1 onion, finely chopped, 2 green chilies, finely chopped, 2 cloves of garlic, minced, 1 tablespoon mustard oil (or any cooking oil), Salt to taste, Fresh coriander leaves for garnish, Lemon wedges for serving
instruction: Wash the potatoes thoroughly and boil them until they are tender. Allow them to cool slightly, then peel and mash them in a mixing bowl. , Heat mustard oil in a pan over medium heat. Add minced garlic and chopped green chilies. Sauté for a minute until aromatic. , Add finely chopped onions to the pan and cook until they turn translucent. , Now, add the mashed potatoes to the pan and mix well with the onion mixture. , Add chopped tomatoes to the mixture and stir everything together. , Season the mixture with salt according to taste and continue to cook for another 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally. , Once the flavors have melded together, remove the pan from heat and transfer the Aloo Chokha to a serving dish. , Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with lemon wedges on the side.

name: Besan Ki Barfi
description: Besan Ki Barfi is a sweet treat bursting with nutty gram flour (besan) flavor. Imagine a dense fudge made with chickpea flour, cooked down with sugar and ghee until it reaches a melt-in-your-mouth consistency. Often flavored with cardamom or pistachios for an extra touch, this delightful confection is perfect for satisfying your sweet tooth or sharing with loved ones during festivals.
ingredients: 1 cup besan (gram flour) , 1/2 cup ghee (clarified butter) , 1/2 cup sugar , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , 2 tablespoons chopped nuts (almonds, cashews, pistachios)
instruction: Heat ghee in a non-stick pan over medium heat. Add besan to the pan and roast it on low to medium heat, stirring continuously until it turns golden brown and aromatic. This will take about 10-12 minutes. Once besan is roasted, add sugar and cardamom powder to it. Mix well until sugar melts completely and the mixture thickens. Add chopped nuts and mix again. Transfer the mixture to a greased plate or tray and spread it evenly. Let it cool down for a few minutes, then cut it into desired shapes (squares or diamonds). Allow it to cool completely before serving. Besan Ki Barfi is ready to enjoy!

name: Kaju Pulao
description: Kaju Pulao is a luxurious vegetarian rice dish studded with plump cashews (kaju) for a delightful textural contrast. Fragrant basmati rice is cooked with aromatic spices like cardamom, cloves, and bay leaves, infusing each fluffy grain with warm flavor. The addition of colorful vegetables like carrots and peas adds a touch of vibrancy, making this dish a feast for both the eyes and the taste buds.
ingredients: 1 cup Basmati rice , 1/2 cup cashew nuts (kaju), whole or halved , 1 onion, thinly sliced , 2 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1-inch ginger, finely chopped , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1/4 cup green peas , 1/4 cup carrots, diced , 1/4 cup bell peppers, diced (optional) , 2 tablespoons ghee or oil , 2 cups water , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Rinse the basmati rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Soak the rice in water for 30 minutes, then drain and set aside. Heat ghee or oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add the cashew nuts and fry until golden brown. Remove the cashews from the pan and set aside. In the same pan, add the sliced onions and sauté until translucent. Add the chopped ginger, minced garlic, and slit green chilies. Sauté for another minute until fragrant. Add the diced carrots, green peas, and bell peppers (if using). Cook for 2-3 minutes until the vegetables are slightly tender. Add the soaked and drained rice to the pan. Stir well to combine with the vegetables. Pour in 2 cups of water and season with salt according to taste. Bring the mixture to a boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low, cover the pan with a lid, and let the rice simmer for about 15-20 minutes, or until the rice is cooked through and the water is absorbed. Once the rice is cooked, fluff it gently with a fork. Garnish with the fried cashew nuts and fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot as a standalone dish or as a side with your favorite curry.

name: Kuttu Ki Puri
description: Kuttu Ki Puri offers a delightful twist on the classic Indian puri. Buckwheat flour (kuttu) takes center stage, forming the base of this crispy treat. Unlike its wheat flour counterpart, kuttu ki puri is naturally gluten-free, making it a great option for those with dietary restrictions. The dough is simply shaped into rounds and deep-fried until golden and puffy, resulting in a light and airy puri perfect for scooping up your favorite curries or savoring on its own.
ingredients: 1 cup buckwheat flour (kuttu ka atta) , 1 medium-sized boiled and mashed potato , 1 green chili, finely chopped (optional) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon black pepper powder , 1/2 teaspoon rock salt (sendha namak), or to taste , Water, as needed , Oil for deep frying
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine buckwheat flour, mashed potato, chopped green chili (if using), cumin seeds, black pepper powder, and rock salt. Gradually add water and knead into a smooth dough. The dough should be soft and pliable but not too sticky. Cover the dough and let it rest for 10 minutes. Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Divide the dough into small lemon-sized balls. Take one ball at a time and roll it into a small puri using a rolling pin and a dusting of buckwheat flour to prevent sticking. Carefully slide the rolled puri into the hot oil and fry until it puffs up and turns golden brown on both sides. Flip as needed to ensure even frying. Once the puris are golden brown and crispy, remove them from the oil using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on paper towels. Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls. Serve the hot and crispy Kuttu Ki Puris with yogurt or any fasting curry of your choice.

name: Kachumber Salad
description: Kachumber Salad is a refreshing and vibrant accompaniment that bursts with flavor in every bite. Imagine chopped onions, tomatoes, cucumbers, and cilantro tossed together with a hint of lime juice and a sprinkle of salt. This simple salad provides a cool and contrasting counterpoint to richer Indian dishes, making it a delightful addition to any meal.
ingredients: 2 medium-sized tomatoes, diced , 1 cucumber, diced , 1 onion, finely chopped , 1 green chili, finely chopped (optional) , 1/4 cup fresh cilantro, chopped , 1 tablespoon lemon juice , Salt to taste , 1/2 teaspoon roasted cumin powder , 1/4 teaspoon black pepper powder
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine diced tomatoes, cucumber, chopped onion, green chili (if using), and chopped cilantro. Add lemon juice, salt, roasted cumin powder, and black pepper powder to the bowl. Toss everything together until well combined. Taste and adjust seasoning if needed. Serve chilled as a refreshing side dish or accompaniment to your main meal.

name: Beetroot Raita
description: Cool and refreshing, Beetroot Raita is a vibrant condiment bursting with color. Creamy yogurt is swirled with earthy, sweet beets, offering a delightful textural contrast. A hint of spice and fresh herbs adds another layer of flavor, making it the perfect accompaniment to a spicy Indian meal.
ingredients: 2 medium-sized beetroots, boiled, peeled, and grated , 1 cup plain yogurt , 1/2 teaspoon roasted cumin powder , 1/4 teaspoon black salt , 1/4 teaspoon red chili powder (optional) , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: In a mixing bowl, whisk the plain yogurt until smooth. Add the grated beetroot to the yogurt and mix well. Season with roasted cumin powder, black salt, red chili powder (if using), and salt to taste. Mix until all the ingredients are well combined. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Chill in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes before serving to allow the flavors to meld together. Serve chilled as a side dish with your favorite Indian meal or as a healthy snack.

name: Sabudana Tikki
description: Sabudana Tikki is a delightful vegetarian fritter made with tapioca pearls (sabudana). Imagine tiny spheres of sago transformed into a savory and crispy delight. Spiced with fragrant notes and flecked with fresh coriander, these tikkis are often pan-fried until golden brown, offering a delightful textural contrast between the soft interior and the crisp exterior. Enjoyed on their own or with chutney for dipping, Sabudana Tikki is a perfect snack or light meal.
ingredients: 1 cup sabudana (tapioca pearls) , 2 medium-sized potatoes, boiled and mashed , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 1/4 cup roasted peanuts, coarsely ground , 1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh coriander leaves , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Oil for frying
instruction: Rinse sabudana under running water until the water runs clear. Soak sabudana in water for 3-4 hours or overnight until they become soft and fluffy. Drain excess water. In a mixing bowl, combine soaked sabudana, mashed potatoes, chopped green chilies, ground peanuts, chopped coriander leaves, cumin seeds, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well to form a dough-like mixture. Divide the mixture into equal-sized portions and shape them into small tikkis or patties. Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Once the oil is hot, carefully place the tikkis in the pan and fry them until golden brown and crispy on both sides. Remove the tikkis from the pan and place them on a plate lined with paper towels to absorb excess oil. Serve hot sabudana tikkis with mint chutney or yogurt dip.

name: Masala Bread
description: Masala Bread is a fusion of savory and fluffy! Imagine soft white bread generously filled with a vibrant mix of spiced vegetables. This versatile delight can be enjoyed toasted for a warm breakfast or at room temperature for a satisfying lunch or snack.
ingredients: 4 slices of bread , 2 medium onions, finely chopped , 2 medium tomatoes, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon garam masala , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 tablespoon oil , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn translucent. Add chopped green chilies and tomatoes. Cook until tomatoes are soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and garam masala. Mix well and cook for another 2 minutes. Season with salt according to taste. Toast the bread slices until they are lightly golden brown. Spread the prepared masala mixture evenly over the toasted bread slices. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot and enjoy the spicy masala bread as a snack or breakfast item.

name: Roomali Roti
description: Roomali Roti, literally meaning "handkerchief bread," lives up to its name with its delicate, thin texture. Made with refined wheat flour, the dough is stretched paper-thin, creating a web-like structure. Cooked on a tawa until speckled with brown spots, these melt-in-your-mouth flatbreads are perfect for scooping up curries or enjoying with rich gravies.
ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour (maida) , 1/4 cup warm water , 1/4 cup yogurt , 1 tablespoon oil or ghee , Salt to taste , Butter or ghee for brushing (optional)
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, salt, yogurt, and oil or ghee. Mix well. Slowly add warm water to the flour mixture and knead into a soft, smooth dough. Cover the dough and let it rest for 30 minutes. After resting, divide the dough into small lemon-sized balls. Take one dough ball and roll it into a thin, translucent disc on a floured surface. The roti should be as thin as possible. Heat a tawa (flat griddle) over medium heat. Once hot, carefully transfer the rolled roti onto the tawa. Cook the roti for about 1-2 minutes on one side until small bubbles start to appear. Flip the roti and cook for another 1-2 minutes on the other side until light brown spots appear. Remove the cooked roti from the tawa and place it on a plate. Optionally, brush with butter or ghee. Repeat the process with the remaining dough balls.

name: Strawberry Lassi
