After resting, knead the dough again and divide it into small lemon-sized balls. Roll each ball into a small puri using a rolling pin. Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Fry the puris until they puff up and turn golden brown. Remove and drain excess oil on paper towels. Let them cool. In a separate bowl, mix tamarind pulp, water, chaat masala, roasted cumin powder, black salt, and red chili powder to prepare the tangy water. Make a small hole in each puri using your thumb. Fill each puri with a spoonful of mashed potatoes, boiled chickpeas, chopped onions, and coriander leaves. Arrange the stuffed golgappas on a serving plate. Pour the prepared tangy water into each golgappa using a spoon or a small funnel. Optionally, drizzle mint chutney and tamarind chutney over the golgappas for added flavor. Garnish with sev. Serve immediately and enjoy the burst of flavors in each bite!

name: Paneer Malai Tikka
description: Paneer Malai Tikka is an indulgent vegetarian dish where cubes of paneer cheese are marinated in a creamy blend of yogurt, spices, and nuts. The marinated paneer is then grilled or pan-fried until crisp on the outside and melt-in-your-mouth tender on the inside. This rich and flavorful appetizer or Main Course is sure to tantalize your taste buds.
ingredients: 250 grams paneer (Indian cottage cheese), cut into cubes , 1/2 cup thick yogurt , 2 tablespoons fresh cream (malai) , 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon garam masala , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon cumin powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste) , 1 tablespoon lemon juice , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon oil , Chopped coriander leaves for garnish , Lemon wedges for serving , Onion rings and mint chutney for serving (optional)
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine yogurt, fresh cream, ginger-garlic paste, garam masala, coriander powder, cumin powder, turmeric powder, red chili powder, lemon juice, and salt to taste. Mix well to form a smooth marinade. Add the paneer cubes to the marinade and gently toss until the paneer cubes are well coated. Cover the bowl and marinate in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld. Preheat the grill or oven to medium-high heat. If using wooden skewers, soak them in water for 30 minutes to prevent burning. Thread the marinated paneer cubes onto skewers, leaving a little space between each cube. Brush the paneer cubes with oil to prevent them from drying out while grilling. Grill the paneer skewers for about 10-12 minutes, turning occasionally, until they are golden brown and slightly charred on the edges. Once cooked, remove the paneer tikka from the grill and transfer them to a serving plate. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve hot with lemon wedges, onion rings, and mint chutney on the side.

name: Lucknowi Biryani
description: Lucknowi Veg Biryani is a flavorful symphony of aromatic rice layered with a medley of Lucknowi vegetables. Fragrant spices like cloves, cardamom, and bay leaves perfume the basmati rice, while succulent peas, potatoes, and cauliflower florets add pops of color and texture. This delightful vegetarian twist on the classic biryani is a feast for the senses, perfect for a celebratory meal.
ingredients: 1 cup Basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes and drained , 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, potatoes, beans) , 1 onion, thinly sliced , 1 tomato, chopped , 1/2 cup plain yogurt , 2 tablespoons ghee (clarified butter) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2-3 green cardamom pods , 1-inch cinnamon stick , 3-4 cloves , 1 bay leaf , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon biryani masala , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves, chopped for garnish , Fried onions for garnish (optional) , Saffron strands soaked in warm milk for garnish (optional)
instruction: Heat ghee in a large pot or pressure cooker. Add cumin seeds, cardamom pods, cinnamon stick, cloves, and bay leaf. Saute until fragrant. Add sliced onions and sauté until golden brown. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn mushy. Stir in mixed vegetables and cook for 2-3 minutes. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, biryani masala, and salt. Mix well. Add soaked and drained Basmati rice to the pot. Gently mix with the vegetable mixture. Pour yogurt over the rice and vegetables. Mix gently to combine. Add enough water to cover the rice by about an inch. Bring to a boil. Once boiling, reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for about 15-20 minutes until the rice is tender and cooked through. Once cooked, fluff the rice gently with a fork. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves, fried onions, and saffron milk. Serve hot with raita (yogurt dip) or any side dish of your choice.

name: Arbi Ke Patte Ke Pakode
description: Tender colocasia leaves are dipped in a spiced gram flour batter, creating a crispy and flavorful exterior. The contrasting textures of the soft leaves and the crunchy batter make for a delightful bite. Enjoy these fritters on their own as a tea-time snack or pair them with chutney for an added layer of flavor.
ingredients: Colocasia leaves (Arbi ke patte) - 10-12 , Besan (Gram flour) - 1 cup , Rice flour - 2 tablespoons , Ajwain (Carom seeds) - 1 teaspoon , Hing (Asafoetida) - 1/4 teaspoon , Red chili powder - 1 teaspoon , Turmeric powder - 1/2 teaspoon , Salt - to taste , Water - as needed , Oil - for frying
instruction: Wash and pat dry the colocasia leaves. Remove the stems and veins. In a bowl, mix besan, rice flour, ajwain, hing, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Gradually add water to make a smooth batter of pouring consistency. Heat oil in a deep frying pan. Dip each colocasia leaf into the batter, ensuring it's coated evenly. Carefully place the coated leaf into the hot oil and fry until golden brown and crisp. Remove from oil and place on paper towels to drain excess oil. Serve hot with chutney or sauce of your choice.

name: Aloo Chaat
description: Aloo Chaat is a flavor explosion on a plate! Tangy yogurt and chutneys mingle with crispy potato bites, creating a symphony of sweet, sour, and spicy sensations. Topped with chopped onions, cilantro, and a squeeze of lemon, this vibrant street food is a delightful explosion of textures and tastes in every bite.
ingredients: 4 medium potatoes, peeled and cubed , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon chaat masala , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon cumin powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons chopped fresh coriander leaves , 2 tablespoons tamarind chutney , 2 tablespoons mint chutney , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 1 small tomato, finely chopped , Sev (crispy chickpea noodles) for garnish , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish , Lemon wedges for serving
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the cubed potatoes and fry until golden brown and crispy. Remove the fried potatoes from the pan and place them on a paper towel to drain excess oil. In a large mixing bowl, toss the fried potatoes with chaat masala, red chili powder, cumin powder, and salt until evenly coated. Transfer the seasoned potatoes to a serving plate. Drizzle tamarind chutney and mint chutney over the potatoes. Sprinkle chopped onions and tomatoes on top. Garnish with sev and fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with lemon wedges on the side.

name: Katori Chaat
description: Katori Chaat is a delightful explosion of textures and flavors in a crispy edible "cup." Imagine tiny fried flour baskets (katoris) overflowing with a savory chickpea (chana) base, tangy yogurt, sweet and spicy chutneys, and a sprinkle of fresh pomegranate seeds for a burst of jewel-like color. This street food favorite is a symphony of sweet, savory, tangy, and spicy, perfect for satisfying a chaat craving.
ingredients: 1 cup chickpeas (cooked) , 2 large potatoes (boiled and chopped) , 1 onion (finely chopped) , 1 tomato (finely chopped) , 1 green chili (finely chopped) , 1/4 cup tamarind chutney , 1/4 cup mint-coriander chutney , 1/2 cup yogurt (whisked) , 1 teaspoon chaat masala , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon cumin powder , Salt to taste , Oil for frying , Fresh coriander leaves (for garnish) , Sev (fried gram flour vermicelli, for garnish)
instruction: Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. In a bowl, mix together boiled potatoes, cooked chickpeas, chopped onions, tomatoes, green chili, chaat masala, red chili powder, cumin powder, and salt. Take small portions of this mixture and shape them into small cups or baskets. Carefully drop these baskets into the hot oil and fry until they turn golden brown and crispy. Remove and drain excess oil on paper towels. Once the baskets are cooled slightly, fill each one with a spoonful of whisked yogurt, tamarind chutney, and mint-coriander chutney. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and sev. Serve immediately and enjoy the delicious Katori Chaat!

name: Cheese Pakora
description: Cheese Pakora is a delightful vegetarian fritter that's perfect for snacking or appetizers. Cubes of your favorite cheese are enveloped in a chickpea flour (gram flour) batter seasoned with aromatic spices. Deep-fried until golden brown and crispy on the outside, the result is a delightful contrast between the gooey cheese center and the crunchy exterior.
ingredients: 200g Paneer (Indian cottage cheese), grated , 1 cup Chickpea flour (besan) , 1/4 cup Rice flour , 1/2 teaspoon Turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon Red chili powder , 1 teaspoon Garam masala , 1 teaspoon Chaat masala , Salt, to taste , Water, as needed , Oil, for deep frying
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine grated paneer, chickpea flour, rice flour, turmeric powder, red chili powder, garam masala, chaat masala, and salt. Gradually add water while mixing to form a thick batter. Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Drop spoonfuls of the batter into the hot oil and fry until golden brown and crispy. Remove the pakoras from the oil and drain excess oil on paper towels. Serve hot with chutney or sauce of your choice.

name: Tomato Chutney
description: Tangy tomatoes are transformed into a sweet and spicy chutney in this vibrant condiment. Spices like cumin and coriander dance with a hint of chili, creating a flavorful explosion. This chutney adds a delightful kick to your favorite dishes, whether served alongside samosas or spooned over rice for a burst of zesty goodness.
ingredients: 500g ripe tomatoes, chopped , 1 medium onion, finely chopped , 2-3 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch piece of ginger, grated , 2-3 green chilies, chopped , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , 2 tablespoons oil , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions, minced garlic, grated ginger, and green chilies. Saute until onions turn translucent. Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are soft and mushy. Mash the tomatoes with the back of a spoon to get a chunky consistency. Add garam masala and cook for another 2-3 minutes until the chutney thickens. Adjust seasoning according to taste. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve tomato chutney with dosa, idli, rice, or any Indian meal.

name: Traditional Sambar
description: South India's comforting Sambar is a hearty lentil stew bursting with flavor. Aromatic sambar powder, simmered with plump lentils and colorful vegetables, creates a tangy base. The magic touch comes from the addition of tamarind, adding a delightful sour note that perfectly complements the warmth of the spices. Enjoyed with rice or dosa, Sambar is a vegetarian staple that warms the soul with every satisfying spoonful.
ingredients: 1 cup toor dal (pigeon peas) , 2 cups mixed vegetables (such as carrots, potatoes, drumsticks, and eggplant), chopped , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 2 tablespoons sambar powder , 1 tablespoon tamarind paste , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2-3 dried red chilies , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , 1 sprig curry leaves , 2 tablespoons oil , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Wash the toor dal thoroughly and pressure cook with enough water until soft and mushy. In a separate pan, heat oil and add mustard seeds. Once they splutter, add cumin seeds, dried red chilies, and asafoetida. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown. Then, add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn mushy. Add the mixed vegetables and cook for 5-7 minutes until they are partially cooked. Now, add sambar powder, tamarind paste, and salt. Mix well. Pour in the cooked toor dal along with its water. Stir everything together and bring it to a boil. Let the sambar simmer for 10-15 minutes until the vegetables are fully cooked and the flavors are well blended. Adjust the consistency by adding more water if needed. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with steamed rice or idli/dosa.

name: Masala Dosa
description: Masala dosa is a South Indian breakfast masterpiece. Imagine a crispy, thin crepe made from fermented rice and lentil batter. This crepe is then transformed into a flavor bomb by encasing a spiced potato filling, traditionally cooked with onions, curry leaves, and mustard seeds. The combination of textures, from the dosa's crispiness to the soft, savory potato filling, is a true delight. Often served with chutneys and sambar for dipping, masala dosa is a satisfying and flavorful way to start your day.
ingredients: For Dosa Batter: 1 cup rice , 1/2 cup urad dal (split black gram) , Water, as needed , Salt, to taste , For Potato Filling (Masala): 4 medium-sized potatoes, boiled and mashed , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder (optional) , Salt, to taste , Fresh coriander leaves, chopped , 2 tablespoons oil
instruction: Prepare Dosa Batter: Rinse rice and urad dal separately and soak them in water for 4-6 hours. Grind the soaked rice and dal separately to a fine paste, adding water as needed. Mix both pastes together in a large bowl, add salt, and let it ferment overnight or for at least 8 hours. Make Potato Filling (Masala): Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds, and let them splutter. Add cumin seeds and asafoetida, followed by chopped onions and green chilies. Saute until onions turn translucent. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder (if using), and mashed potatoes. Mix well. Season with salt and cook for a few minutes until flavors meld together. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and set aside. Cook Masala Dosa: Heat a non-stick or cast-iron skillet over medium heat. Pour a ladleful of dosa batter onto the center of the skillet and spread it in a circular motion to form a thin crepe. Drizzle some oil or ghee around the edges of the dosa and cook until the bottom turns golden brown and crispy. Spread a spoonful of potato filling (masala) on one half of the dosa. Fold the dosa in half, covering the filling, and gently press down with a spatula. Cook for another minute until the dosa is crisp and golden brown on both sides. Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Rava Upma
description: Rava Upma is a comforting South Indian breakfast dish made with semolina flour (rava). Imagine toasted semolina cooked in a flavorful broth infused with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and fresh chopped vegetables. The result is a light, fluffy, and savory porridge bursting with warm spices and textures. It's a quick and delicious way to start your day.
ingredients: 1 cup rava (semolina) , 2 cups water , 2 tablespoons oil or ghee , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon urad dal (split black gram) , 1 teaspoon chana dal (split chickpeas) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 1 green chili, finely chopped , 1-inch piece of ginger, finely chopped , 2-3 tablespoons chopped vegetables (carrots, peas, bell peppers, etc.) , A few curry leaves , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Dry roast the rava in a pan over low heat until it turns light golden brown. Set aside. Heat oil or ghee in a pan and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter. Add urad dal and chana dal. Fry until they turn golden brown. Add chopped onions, green chilies, and ginger. Saute until onions turn translucent. Add chopped vegetables and curry leaves. Cook for a few minutes until the vegetables are slightly tender. Pour water into the pan and add salt and asafoetida. Bring it to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and slowly add the roasted rava while stirring continuously to avoid lumps. Cook for 5-7 minutes until the upma thickens and the rava is cooked completely. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot.

name: Rava Idli
description: Rava Idli is a fluffy and savory South Indian breakfast made with semolina (rava). Unlike traditional idli made with rice batter, this instant version is quicker to prepare. The semolina is combined with yogurt for a slight tang, along with spices like curry leaves and mustard seeds for a burst of flavor. These steamed cakes are typically enjoyed with a dollop of chutney and sambar for a delightful and satisfying meal.
ingredients: 1 cup semolina (rava) , 1 cup yogurt (curd) , 1/2 cup water , 1/4 cup grated carrots , 1/4 cup finely chopped cilantro , 1/4 cup finely chopped green chilies , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon baking soda , Salt to taste , Oil for greasing idli molds
instruction: Heat a pan and dry roast the semolina (rava) until it turns light golden brown. Transfer it to a bowl and let it cool. In the same pan, heat a little oil and add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add grated carrots and chopped green chilies to the pan. Saute for 2-3 minutes. Add the sautéed mixture to the roasted semolina. Now, add yogurt, water, chopped cilantro, baking soda, and salt to the semolina mixture. Mix well to form a smooth batter. Let it rest for 10 minutes. Meanwhile, grease the idli molds with oil. After 10 minutes, pour the batter into the greased idli molds. Steam the idlis in a steamer for about 12-15 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Once done, remove the idlis from the molds and serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Tomato Rasam
description: Tangy and comforting, Tomato Rasam is a South Indian soup that bursts with flavor. Juicy tomatoes are simmered with a touch of tamarind for a delightful sourness, balanced by the warmth of aromatic spices. Fresh coriander adds a bright, herbaceous note, making this light and flavorful soup the perfect accompaniment to a comforting meal of rice and sambar.
ingredients: 3 ripe tomatoes, chopped , 1 tablespoon tamarind paste , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2 dried red chilies , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon asafoetida (hing) , 1 sprig curry leaves , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch piece ginger, grated , 2 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1 tablespoon coriander leaves, chopped , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon ghee or oil , 4 cups water
instruction: Heat ghee or oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add cumin seeds, dried red chilies, curry leaves, minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chilies. Saute for a minute. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn mushy. Add turmeric powder, asafoetida, and tamarind paste. Mix well. Pour in 4 cups of water and season with salt. Let it simmer for 10-12 minutes. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and turn off the heat. Serve hot with steamed rice or enjoy as a soup.

name: Onion Dosa
description: Onion Dosa is a South Indian staple, a crispy and savory crepe unlike any other. Imagine a fermented batter made with rice and lentils, transformed into a thin, lace-like crepe on a griddle. The star of the show is a caramelized onion filling, adding a burst of sweetness and depth of flavor. This delightful dosa is a perfect breakfast or light meal, enjoyed with sambar and coconut chutney for a complete and satisfying experience.
ingredients: 1 cup rice , 1/2 cup urad dal (black gram dal) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2-3 green chilies, finely chopped , Handful of fresh coriander leaves, chopped , Salt to taste , Oil for cooking
instruction: Wash and soak rice and urad dal separately in water for about 4-6 hours or overnight. After soaking, drain the water and grind rice and urad dal separately to a smooth paste using a little water. Mix both the batters together in a large bowl and add salt. Mix well and let it ferment for 8-10 hours or overnight. After fermentation, add finely chopped onions, green chilies, and coriander leaves to the batter. Mix well. Heat a non-stick dosa tawa (griddle) over medium heat. Pour a ladleful of batter onto the tawa and spread it in a circular motion to form a thin dosa. Drizzle a little oil around the edges of the dosa and cook until the bottom turns golden brown and crispy. Flip the dosa and cook the other side until it's cooked through. Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Medu Vada
description: Medu Vada are crispy South Indian fritters that pack a flavorful punch. Fluffy urad dal batter, seasoned with fragrant herbs and spices, is transformed into golden spheres through a quick fry. These savory delights are typically enjoyed dipped in sambar or chutney, offering a delightful textural and taste contrast in every bite.
ingredients: 1 cup urad dal (black gram dal) , 2-3 green chilies, finely chopped , 1-inch piece of ginger, grated , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Salt to taste , Oil for deep frying
instruction: Wash and soak the urad dal in water for at least 4-6 hours or overnight. Drain the soaked dal and transfer it to a blender or food processor. Grind the dal into a smooth and thick batter, adding minimal water if necessary. The batter should be fluffy and light. Transfer the batter to a mixing bowl. Add chopped green chilies, grated ginger, cumin seeds, asafoetida, and salt. Mix well to combine. Heat oil in a deep frying pan or kadhai over medium heat. Wet your hands with water to prevent the batter from sticking. Take a small portion of the batter and shape it into a round disc with a hole in the center, resembling a doughnut. Gently slide the shaped vada into the hot oil, frying 2-3 vadas at a time depending on the size of your pan. Fry the vadas until they turn golden brown and crispy on all sides, turning occasionally for even cooking. Once done, remove the vadas using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on a paper towel. Serve hot Medu Vadas with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Veg Kurma
description: Veg Kurma is a rich and flavorful curry that explodes with taste and texture. Tender vegetables are simmered in a creamy sauce infused with warming spices, aromatics like onions and tomatoes, and a hint of fragrant fenugreek. This delightful dish is a perfect centerpiece for a vegetarian meal, ideal for scooping up with rice or naan.
ingredients: 2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, potatoes, peas) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 1/2 cup coconut milk , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1-inch ginger, minced , 3-4 garlic cloves, minced , 2 green chilies, slit , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon chili powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. Once they splutter, add cumin seeds and let them crackle. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown. Add minced ginger, garlic, and slit green chilies. Sauté for a minute. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, chili powder, coriander powder, and garam masala. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes. Add mixed vegetables and mix until they are well coated with the spices. Pour coconut milk and mix everything together. Add salt to taste. Cover and cook for 15-20 minutes or until the vegetables are cooked through. Once done, garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or chapati.

name: Lemon Rice
description: Lemon Rice is a refreshingly simple South Indian dish. Fluffy cooked rice is tossed with a vibrant tempering of mustard seeds, curry leaves, and chilies. The magic touch comes with a squeeze of fresh lemon juice, creating a delightful dance of tangy and savory flavors. Often garnished with chopped coriander leaves for an extra pop of color, this light and flavorful dish is perfect for a quick lunch or a comforting side.
ingredients: 1 cup long-grain white rice , 2 cups water , 2 tablespoons oil (preferably sesame or vegetable oil) , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/4 cup roasted peanuts (optional) , 2 green chilies, chopped , 8-10 curry leaves , 1/4 cup chopped cilantro (coriander leaves) , Salt to taste , Juice of 1 lemon , Lemon zest (optional, for garnish)
instruction: Rinse the rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain well. In a medium saucepan, bring 2 cups of water to a boil. Add the rice, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the rice is cooked and all the water is absorbed. Fluff the rice with a fork and set aside to cool slightly. In a large skillet or frying pan, heat the oil over medium heat. Add the mustard seeds and cumin seeds and cook for 1-2 minutes until they start to splutter. Add the turmeric powder, roasted peanuts (if using), chopped green chilies, and curry leaves. Stir well and cook for another 2-3 minutes. Add the cooked rice to the skillet and toss gently to combine with the spices. Season with salt to taste and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes until everything is well heated through. Remove from heat and stir in the chopped cilantro and lemon juice. Garnish with lemon zest if desired. Serve hot as a side dish or as a light Main Course.

name: Kesari
description: Kesari Bhath, also known as Kesari, is a vibrant sweet dish bursting with saffron's warm aroma. Semolina (sooji) is cooked in sugar syrup infused with saffron, cardamom, and ghee. The result is a melt-in-your-mouth sweet dish, often garnished with nuts and raisins for a delightful textural and visual contrast. Perfect for festivals, potlucks, or a satisfying sweet treat!
ingredients: 1 cup semolina (sooji/rava) , 1/2 cup ghee (clarified butter) , 1 cup sugar , 2 cups water , A pinch of saffron strands , 1/4 cup chopped nuts (almonds, cashews, pistachios) , 1/4 teaspoon ground cardamom , A few strands of saffron for garnish (optional)
instruction: Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium heat. Add chopped nuts and roast until golden brown. Remove and set aside. In the same pan, add semolina and roast until it turns aromatic and light golden brown. Keep stirring to prevent burning. In a separate saucepan, heat water until it boils. Add saffron strands to the boiling water and let it infuse for a few minutes. Slowly pour the saffron-infused water into the roasted semolina while stirring continuously to avoid lumps. Add sugar and ground cardamom to the mixture and continue stirring until the sugar dissolves completely. Cook the mixture on low heat until it thickens and starts leaving the sides of the pan. Keep stirring to prevent sticking. Once the kesari reaches the desired consistency, remove it from heat and garnish with roasted nuts and saffron strands. Serve hot or cold, as desired.

name: Lemon Rasam
description: Lemon Rasam is a tangy and invigorating soup, perfect for a light meal or as a digestive aid. Imagine a clear broth bursting with the citrusy flavor of lemons, balanced by the warmth of cumin and the earthy depth of peppercorns. Topped with fresh coriander leaves for an extra pop of freshness, this comforting soup is a delightful way to tantalize your taste buds.
ingredients: 1/2 cup split pigeon peas (toor dal), washed and soaked for 30 minutes , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 1 lemon, juiced , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon black peppercorns , 2-3 dried red chilies , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon asafoetida (hing) , Few curry leaves , 2 cloves garlic, minced , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons chopped coriander leaves for garnish , 1 tablespoon ghee or oil
instruction: Cook the soaked split pigeon peas in a pressure cooker with water until soft and mushy. Mash and set aside. In a pan, heat ghee or oil. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add cumin seeds, black peppercorns, dried red chilies, and curry leaves. Saute for a minute. Add minced garlic and saute until golden brown. Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are soft and mushy. Add the cooked split pigeon peas (toor dal) along with some water to adjust the consistency. Let the rasam simmer for 5-7 minutes until flavors blend well. Turn off the heat and add freshly squeezed lemon juice. Stir well. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with steamed rice or enjoy as a soup.

name: Paniyaram
description: Paniyaram, a South Indian delight, are bite-sized savory dumplings. Imagine fluffy fermented batter, traditionally made with rice and lentils, flecked with bits of onion, chilies, and sometimes fresh coconut. This flavorful batter is dolloped into a special mold with round indentations and cooked until golden brown and crispy on the outside, with a soft and fluffy center. Enjoyed with chutney or sambar, paniyaram is a delightful breakfast, snack, or even a light meal.
ingredients: 1 cup raw rice , 1/4 cup urad dal (black gram lentils) , 1/4 cup poha (flattened rice) , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 1/4 cup jaggery (or to taste) , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , A pinch of salt , 1 tablespoon ghee (clarified butter) , Oil for greasing the paniyaram pan
instruction: Wash and soak raw rice, urad dal, and poha together in water for 4-6 hours. Drain the water and grind the soaked ingredients into a smooth batter. The consistency should be similar to dosa batter. Transfer the batter into a bowl and add grated coconut, jaggery, cardamom powder, and a pinch of salt. Mix well. Heat the paniyaram pan and add a few drops of ghee into each mold. Pour spoonfuls of batter into each mold, filling them up to 3/4th. Cook on medium-low heat for 3-4 minutes or until the bottom turns golden brown. Flip each paniyaram using a skewer or spoon and cook the other side until golden brown. Once cooked, remove from the pan and repeat the process with the remaining batter. Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Dal Vada
description: Dal Vada are savory fritters packed with protein and flavor. Lentils (dal) are spiced with fragrant ingredients like cumin, coriander, and chilies, then formed into patties and deep-fried until golden brown and crispy. These delicious fritters can be enjoyed on their own as a snack or dunked in creamy yogurt or chutney for a delightful appetizer or side dish.
ingredients: 1 cup chana dal (split chickpeas) , 2-3 green chilies, finely chopped , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 2 tablespoons chopped coriander leaves , 1 teaspoon grated ginger , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/4 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , Oil for deep frying
instruction: Wash the chana dal thoroughly and soak it in water for 2-3 hours. Drain the water from the dal and transfer it to a blender or food processor. Grind the dal into a coarse paste without adding water. The mixture should be slightly grainy. Transfer the ground dal to a mixing bowl. Add chopped green chilies, onion, coriander leaves, grated ginger, cumin seeds, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix everything well to form a thick batter. Heat oil in a deep frying pan or kadhai over medium heat. Take a small portion of the batter and shape it into a flat round vada. Gently slide the vada into the hot oil and fry in batches until golden brown and crispy. Once done, remove the vadas using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on a paper towel. Serve hot with coconut chutney or tomato ketchup.

name: Poha Idli
description: Poha Idli offers a unique twist on the classic South Indian breakfast. Imagine flattened rice (poha) flakes steamed together with lentil batter (like idli) for a soft and fluffy texture. This innovative dish combines the light and savory taste of poha with the satisfying heartiness of lentils, making it a delicious and healthy way to start your day.
ingredients: 1 cup poha (flattened rice) , 1 cup rice flour , 1 cup plain yogurt , 1/2 cup water , 1 teaspoon baking soda , Salt to taste , Finely chopped coriander leaves (optional) , Grated carrot or grated coconut for garnish (optional) , Oil or ghee for greasing idli molds
instruction: Rinse the poha under running water and drain well. Transfer to a mixing bowl. Add rice flour, plain yogurt, and water to the bowl with poha. Mix well to form a smooth batter. Cover the batter and let it ferment for 4-6 hours or overnight in a warm place. After fermentation, the batter will rise and become fluffy. Add salt to taste and mix well. Grease the idli molds with oil or ghee. Pour the batter into the molds, filling them halfway. Heat water in a steamer. Once the water starts boiling, place the idli molds in the steamer. Steam the idlis for about 12-15 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Once cooked, remove the idli molds from the steamer and let them cool for a few minutes. Carefully unmold the idlis using a spoon or knife. Serve the poha idlis hot with coconut chutney or sambar. Optionally, garnish with finely chopped coriander leaves, grated carrot, or grated coconut before serving.

name: Spicy Mushroom Biryani
description: Spicy Mushroom Biryani takes the classic layered rice dish and gives it a vegetarian twist. Fragrant basmati rice is infused with aromatic spices and layered with perfectly seasoned, pan-fried mushrooms. This flavorful vegetarian biryani is a delightful explosion of textures and tastes, perfect for a satisfying and wholesome meal.
ingredients: 1 cup basmati rice, rinsed and soaked for 30 minutes , 200g mushrooms, cleaned and sliced , 1 large onion, thinly sliced , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 2 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1/2 cup yogurt , 2 tablespoons biryani masala , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 4-5 whole cloves , 2-3 bay leaves , 2-inch cinnamon stick , 4-5 whole peppercorns , 2 tablespoons ghee or vegetable oil , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Heat ghee or oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds, cloves, bay leaves, cinnamon stick, and peppercorns. Saute for a minute until fragrant. Add sliced onions and saute until they turn golden brown. Add chopped tomatoes and green chilies. Cook until tomatoes are soft and mushy. Add sliced mushrooms to the pan and cook for 3-4 minutes until they release their water. In a small bowl, whisk yogurt with biryani masala, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Add the yogurt mixture to the pan and mix well with the mushrooms and onions. Drain the soaked rice and add it to the pan. Stir gently to coat the rice with the masala. Pour 2 cups of water into the pan and bring it to a boil. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pan with a lid, and let it simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the rice is cooked and the water is absorbed. Once done, remove the pan from heat and let it sit covered for 5 minutes. Fluff the biryani gently with a fork. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with raita or salad.

name: Classic Coconut Chutney
description: Classic Coconut Chutney is a symphony of fresh flavors in a simple package. Imagine a smooth blend of shredded coconut, chilies for a touch of heat, and a hint of tanginess. This South Indian staple is often finished with a warm, aromatic tempering of mustard seeds and curry leaves, making it the perfect accompaniment to savory dishes like dosa or idli.
ingredients: 1 cup grated coconut , 2-3 green chilies, chopped , 1/4 cup roasted chana dal (split chickpeas) , 1/4 cup fresh coriander leaves , 1 small piece of ginger , 1 garlic clove , Salt to taste , Water as needed
instruction: In a blender or food processor, combine grated coconut, chopped green chilies, roasted chana dal, coriander leaves, ginger, garlic, and salt. Blend the mixture, gradually adding water until you achieve a smooth consistency. Adjust the water quantity based on your desired thickness. Transfer the chutney to a serving bowl. Optionally, you can temper the chutney by heating a little oil in a pan, adding mustard seeds, curry leaves, and dried red chilies, and pouring this tempering over the chutney. Serve the coconut chutney as a delicious accompaniment to dosa, idli, vada, or any South Indian dish.

name: Poori Masala
description: Poori Masala is a delightful indulgence that combines crispy pooris with a flavorful and comforting masala. Imagine fluffy, deep-fried pooris, dipped in a rich and savory gravy simmered with onions, tomatoes, spices, and your choice of protein (vegetables, paneer, or even keema). This dish is an explosion of textures and tastes, perfect for a celebratory meal or a weekend treat.
ingredients: 4 medium-sized potatoes, boiled and mashed , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, chopped , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , A handful of fresh coriander leaves, chopped , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , For Poori: 2 cups whole wheat flour , Water for kneading , Oil for frying
instruction: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and green chilies. Saute until onions turn translucent. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and garam masala. Mix well. Add mashed potatoes and salt. Stir to combine all the ingredients. Cook for 2-3 minutes. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and remove from heat. Set aside. For Poori: In a large mixing bowl, combine whole wheat flour with a pinch of salt. Gradually add water and knead the dough until smooth and soft. Divide the dough into small lemon-sized balls. Roll each ball into a small circle using a rolling pin. Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Carefully slide the rolled poori into the hot oil and fry until it puffs up and turns golden brown on both sides. Remove the poori from the oil and drain excess oil on a paper towel. Serve hot with the prepared potato masala.

name: Oats Idli
description: Oats idli offers a healthy twist on the classic South Indian breakfast. Imagine steaming hot, fluffy idlis made with a batter of oats instead of rice. The batter is often spiced with fragrant mustard seeds, curry leaves, and chilies for a touch of warmth. Topped with a dollop of coconut chutney, this protein-packed idli is a delightful way to start your day.
ingredients: 1 cup rolled oats , 1/2 cup semolina (sooji) , 1/2 cup yogurt (curd) , 1/2 cup water , 1/2 cup grated carrots , 1/4 cup chopped cilantro (coriander leaves) , 1/4 cup grated coconut (optional) , 1 tsp mustard seeds , 1 tsp cumin seeds , 1 tsp urad dal (split black gram) , 1 tsp chana dal (split chickpeas) , 1 green chili, finely chopped , 1 inch ginger, grated , 1/2 tsp baking soda , Salt to taste , Oil for greasing the idli molds
instruction: Dry roast the rolled oats in a pan for 2-3 minutes until lightly golden and fragrant. Let it cool. Grind the roasted oats into a fine powder using a blender or food processor. In a mixing bowl, combine the powdered oats, semolina, yogurt, and water. Mix well to form a thick batter. Let it rest for 30 minutes. In a small pan, heat some oil. Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, urad dal, and chana dal. Saute until the dals turn golden brown. Add chopped green chili and grated ginger to the tempering and saute for a minute. Add the tempering mixture, grated carrots, chopped cilantro, grated coconut (if using), baking soda, and salt to the idli batter. Mix well. Grease the idli molds with oil. Pour the batter into the molds. Steam the idlis in a steamer for 12-15 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Once done, remove the idli molds from the steamer and let them cool for a few minutes. Serve the oats idli hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Onion Chutney
description: Onion chutney is a tangy and versatile condiment made by caramelizing onions until beautifully golden. Spices like cumin and coriander add warmth, while a touch of vinegar or lemon juice provides a refreshing zing. This flavorful chutney complements a variety of dishes, from samosas and pakoras to grilled meats and roasted vegetables.
ingredients: 2 large onions, finely chopped , 2-3 dry red chilies , 1 tablespoon oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon urad dal (black gram lentils) , 1 teaspoon chana dal (split chickpeas) , 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds , 4-5 garlic cloves , Small piece of tamarind (about 1/2 inch) , Salt to taste , Water as needed
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add urad dal, chana dal, and cumin seeds. Saute until dals turn golden brown. Add dry red chilies and garlic cloves. Saute for a minute. Add chopped onions and saute until they turn translucent and golden brown. Once the onions are cooked, add tamarind and salt. Mix well. Allow the mixture to cool down to room temperature. Transfer the cooled mixture to a blender or food processor. Blend into a smooth paste, adding water as needed to achieve the desired consistency. Transfer the chutney to a serving bowl. Serve with dosas, idlis, or rice dishes.

name: Pineapple Kesari
description: Pineapple Kesari is a vibrant sweet dish that's sure to tantalize your taste buds. Semolina pudding (kesari) is infused with the juicy sweetness of pineapples, creating a delightful textural contrast. Rich with ghee, sugar, and a touch of saffron for aromatic depth, this dessert is a perfect way to indulge your sweet tooth or impress your guests with its festive flair.
ingredients: 1 cup semolina (sooji/rava) , 1 cup chopped pineapple , 1/2 cup sugar , 3 cups water , 4 tablespoons ghee (clarified butter) , 1/4 cup chopped cashews , 1/4 cup golden raisins , 1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder , A pinch of saffron strands (optional) , A few drops of pineapple essence (optional)
instruction: Heat 2 tablespoons of ghee in a pan and roast the semolina on low heat until it turns aromatic and slightly golden brown. Set aside. In another pan, heat the remaining ghee and fry the cashews and raisins until they turn golden brown. Remove and set aside. In the same pan, add the chopped pineapple and cook until it softens slightly. Add water to the pan and bring it to a boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low. Slowly add the roasted semolina to the boiling water, stirring continuously to avoid lumps. Cook the mixture until the semolina absorbs all the water and becomes thick. Add sugar, cardamom powder, saffron strands (if using), and pineapple essence (if using). Mix well. Continue to cook until the kesari starts to leave the sides of the pan and becomes glossy. Finally, add the fried cashews and raisins, reserving some for garnish. Remove from heat and transfer the Pineapple Kesari to a serving dish. Garnish with the reserved cashews and raisins. Serve hot and enjoy your delicious Pineapple Kesari!

name: Pattani Kurma
description: Pattani Kurma is a delightful vegetarian curry bursting with fresh flavors. Tender green peas are simmered in a creamy tomato gravy infused with warming spices like coriander, turmeric, and a touch of chili powder. The addition of cashews or almonds lends a rich, nutty depth, while a hint of garam masala adds a touch of aromatic complexity. This flavorful curry is perfect served over rice or mopped up with warm rotis.
ingredients: 1 cup dried white peas (pattani) , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 1 green chili, slit lengthwise , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon chili powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , Coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Soak the dried white peas in water overnight. Drain and rinse them before using. Heat oil in a pan and sauté the chopped onions until they turn golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute until the raw smell disappears. Add chopped tomatoes and green chili. Cook until tomatoes are soft and oil separates. Now, add turmeric powder, chili powder, coriander powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well. Add the soaked white peas and mix until they are well coated with the masala. Add enough water to cover the peas and bring it to a boil. Reduce the heat, cover the pan, and let it simmer until the peas are cooked and the gravy thickens. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves before serving.

name: Onion Sambar
description: Onion Sambar offers a delightful twist on the classic South Indian lentil stew. This comforting dish features a symphony of caramelized onions simmered with fragrant sambar powder, plump lentils, and tangy tamarind. The result? A rich and flavorful vegetarian stew perfect for spooning over steaming rice or savoring with fluffy idlis or crispy dosas.
ingredients: 1 cup toor dal (split pigeon peas) , 2 onions, chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 1/2 cup tamarind pulp , 1 tablespoon sambar powder , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 2 dried red chilies , A pinch of asafoetida (hing) , Few curry leaves , 2 tablespoons oil , Salt to taste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
instruction: Cook the toor dal in a pressure cooker until soft and mushy. Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds. When they splutter, add cumin seeds, dried red chilies, and asafoetida. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn translucent. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft. Add tamarind pulp, sambar powder, turmeric powder, salt, and curry leaves. Mix well and let it simmer for 5 minutes. Add the cooked toor dal to the mixture and mix thoroughly. Add water if needed to adjust the consistency. Let the sambar simmer for another 10-15 minutes on low heat until the flavors blend well. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves before serving.

name: Ven Pongal
description: Ven Pongal is a South Indian comfort food that combines creamy goodness with a touch of warmth. Rice and lentils are cooked together until soft, releasing a comforting porridge-like texture. The magic unfolds with the addition of fragrant ghee, toasted cumin seeds, and a whisper of black pepper. Curry leaves add a final flourish, creating a dish that's both simple and satisfying.
ingredients: 1 cup rice , 1/2 cup split moong dal , 4 cups water , 2 tablespoons ghee (clarified butter) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon black peppercorns , 1-inch piece of ginger, finely chopped , 2-3 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 10-12 cashew nuts , Salt to taste , A few curry leaves , 2 tablespoons chopped coriander leaves (optional)
instruction: Rinse the rice and moong dal together under running water until the water runs clear. Drain and set aside. In a pressure cooker, heat 1 tablespoon of ghee over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and black peppercorns. Sauté for a few seconds until fragrant. Add chopped ginger, slit green chilies, and curry leaves. Sauté for another minute. Add the drained rice and moong dal mixture to the pressure cooker. Stir well to combine with the spices. Pour in 4 cups of water and season with salt to taste. Mix well. Close the pressure cooker with its lid and cook on medium heat for 3-4 whistles or until the rice and dal are cooked thoroughly and mushy. Once the pressure releases naturally, open the cooker and give the Pongal a good stir. If it looks too thick, you can add a little hot water to adjust the consistency. In a separate small pan, heat the remaining tablespoon of ghee. Fry the cashew nuts until golden brown. Pour the fried cashew nuts along with the ghee into the Pongal. Mix well. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves if desired. Serve hot Ven Pongal with coconut chutney and sambar for a traditional South Indian breakfast experience.

name: Baby Potato Fry
description: Tiny potatoes are seasoned with a warming blend of Indian spices, creating a delightful side dish in Baby Potato Fry. These tender morsels are crisped to perfection, offering a textural contrast against the aromatic spice coating. Enjoy them alongside curries, rice, or simply on their own for a satisfying and flavorful snack.
ingredients: 500g baby potatoes, washed and halved , 2 tablespoons olive oil , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon chili powder , 1 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish (optional)
instruction: Heat olive oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add the halved baby potatoes to the pan. Sprinkle turmeric powder, chili powder, garam masala, and salt over the potatoes. Stir well to coat the potatoes evenly with the spices. Cook for about 20-25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes are golden brown and crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. Once cooked, remove from heat and transfer to a serving dish. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves if desired. Serve hot as a delicious side dish or snack.

name: Aval Laddu
description: Aval Laddu are like sweet and nutty energy bites made with flattened rice (aval). Imagine puffed rice flakes bound together with jaggery's rich sweetness, studded with nuts and raisins for a delightful textural surprise. These melt-in-your-mouth treats are perfect for satisfying your sweet tooth or as a quick and healthy snack.
ingredients: 2 cups aval (poha or flattened rice) , 1 cup jaggery, grated , 1/4 cup grated coconut , 1/4 cup ghee (clarified butter) , 1/4 teaspoon cardamom powder , 2 tablespoons chopped nuts (cashews, almonds, etc.)
instruction: Dry roast the aval in a pan over low heat until it turns crisp. Allow it to cool. Grind the roasted aval into a fine powder using a blender or mixer grinder. In the same pan, heat ghee and add grated jaggery. Stir until the jaggery melts completely. Add the ground aval powder, grated coconut, cardamom powder, and chopped nuts to the melted jaggery. Mix well. Turn off the heat and allow the mixture to cool slightly. While the mixture is still warm, take small portions and shape them into laddus by pressing firmly between your palms. Repeat the process with the remaining mixture. Let the laddus cool completely before storing them in an airtight container.

name: Cheru Payar
description: Cheru Payar, also known as green gram curry, is a flavorful lentil dish from Kerala cuisine. Cooked green gram is seasoned with onions, green chilies, garlic, and turmeric, then tempered with curry leaves in coconut oil. Enjoy it as a side dish with rice or puttu for a satisfying meal.
ingredients: 1 cup cheru payar (green gram/moong dal), soaked for 1-2 hours , 2 cups water , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, chopped , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon coconut oil , Curry leaves for garnish.
instruction: Drain the soaked cheru payar and rinse them well. In a pressure cooker, add the rinsed cheru payar along with 2 cups of water, chopped onion, green chilies, minced garlic, turmeric powder, and salt. Pressure cook for 3-4 whistles or until the cheru payar is soft and cooked. Once the pressure releases, open the cooker and gently mash the cheru payar with a ladle. In a separate pan, heat coconut oil and add curry leaves. Fry for a few seconds. Pour this tempering over the cooked cheru payar and mix well. Serve hot with chiratta puttu or rice.

name: Sour and Spicy Okra With Potatoes
description: Sour and Spicy Okra With Potatoes is a tantalizing dish that combines the earthiness of potatoes with the unique flavor and texture of okra. This recipe brings together a harmonious blend of spices, including mustard seeds, cumin, and turmeric, creating a symphony of flavors that dance on the palate. The tanginess from tamarind paste adds a delightful sour note, perfectly balancing the heat from the red chili powder and green chilies. Served hot and garnished with fresh coriander leaves, this dish is a delightful addition to any meal, whether paired with rice or enjoyed with roti.
ingredients: 250g fresh okra (ladyfinger), washed and chopped , 2 medium-sized potatoes, peeled and diced , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , Salt to taste , 1 tablespoon tamarind paste , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish.
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown. Add chopped tomatoes and green chilies. Cook until the tomatoes are soft and mushy. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for another minute. Add diced potatoes and chopped okra. Mix everything together until the vegetables are coated with the spice mixture. Cover the pan and cook for about 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes and okra are cooked through. Once the vegetables are cooked, add tamarind paste and mix well. Cook for another 2-3 minutes to allow the flavors to blend. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Dahi Dal
description: This delectable Dahi Dal combines the creamy richness of yogurt with the wholesome goodness of lentils, creating a comforting and flavorful dish. With its tangy yogurt base and aromatic spices, this recipe offers a perfect balance of textures and flavors. It's a quick and easy dish to prepare, making it ideal for busy weeknights or lazy weekends. Serve it with steamed rice or warm rotis for a satisfying meal that will surely delight your taste buds.
ingredients: 1 cup split yellow lentils (moong dal) , 1 cup plain yogurt (dahi) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons oil , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish.
instruction: Wash the split yellow lentils (moong dal) thoroughly and soak them in water for about 30 minutes. After soaking, drain the water and add the lentils to a pressure cooker along with 2 cups of water, salt, and turmeric powder. Pressure cook for 3-4 whistles or until the lentils are soft and cooked. Once the lentils are cooked, whisk the plain yogurt (dahi) until smooth and creamy. Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds and mustard seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and green chilies to the pan and sauté until the onions turn golden brown. Add chopped tomatoes to the pan and cook until they become soft and mushy. Lower the heat and add red chili powder to the pan. Mix well and cook for another minute. Add the cooked lentils to the pan and mix everything together. Allow the mixture to simmer for 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally. Turn off the heat and gently fold in the whisked yogurt until well combined. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Chickpea-Potato Chaat
description: Chickpea-Potato Chaat is a delightful Indian street food snack that combines the earthy flavors of chickpeas and potatoes with tangy chutneys and aromatic spices. This savory dish features boiled potatoes and tender chickpeas tossed with onions, tomatoes, and fresh cilantro. Seasoned with chaat masala, cumin, and chili powder, it offers a burst of bold flavors in every bite. Finished with a drizzle of tamarind and mint-coriander chutneys, along with a squeeze of lemon juice, this chaat is a symphony of sweet, spicy, and tangy notes. Perfect for a quick snack or a light meal, Chickpea-Potato Chaat is sure to tantalize your taste buds and leave you craving for more.
ingredients: 1 can (15 ounces) chickpeas, drained and rinsed , 2 medium potatoes, boiled, peeled, and diced , 1 small red onion, finely chopped , 1 small tomato, diced , 1 green chili, finely chopped (optional) , 1/4 cup fresh cilantro, chopped , 1 teaspoon chaat masala (Indian spice mix) , 1/2 teaspoon roasted cumin powder , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste) , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons tamarind chutney , 2 tablespoons mint-coriander chutney , Juice of 1 lemon , Sev (crispy chickpea noodles) for garnish (optional).
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine the chickpeas, boiled potatoes, chopped onion, diced tomato, green chili (if using), and chopped cilantro. Add the chaat masala, roasted cumin powder, red chili powder, and salt to taste. Mix well to combine all the ingredients evenly. Add the tamarind chutney, mint-coriander chutney, and lemon juice to the bowl. Gently toss the mixture until everything is coated in the chutneys and lemon juice. Taste and adjust the seasoning according to your preference. Transfer the chaat to serving plates or bowls. Garnish with sev (if using) and additional chopped cilantro if desired. Serve immediately and enjoy the delicious Chickpea-Potato Chaat!

name: Chana Dal With Okra and Coconut
description: A delightful fusion of flavors, this Chana Dal With Okra and Coconut dish combines the nuttiness of chana dal (split Bengal gram lentils) with the earthy taste of okra and the richness of grated coconut. Sautéed with aromatic spices like mustard seeds, cumin seeds, and ginger-garlic paste, and simmered to perfection, this recipe offers a wholesome and satisfying meal option. Enjoy the hearty texture of the dal paired with the tender okra pieces, all infused with the subtle sweetness of coconut. Perfect for a comforting dinner or lunch, this dish promises to tantalize your taste buds with every bite.
ingredients: 1 cup chana dal (split Bengal gram lentils) , 250g okra (ladyfinger), washed and chopped , 1/2 cup grated coconut , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 2 green chilies, chopped , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon cumin powder , Salt to taste , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish.
instruction: Wash and soak the chana dal in water for about 30 minutes. Heat oil in a pressure cooker or a heavy-bottomed pan. Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies. Sauté for a minute. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy. Drain the soaked chana dal and add it to the cooker. Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, and salt. Mix well. Add chopped okra and grated coconut. Mix everything together. Pour water, just enough to cover the ingredients. Close the pressure cooker lid and cook for about 3-4 whistles or until the dal is cooked and soft. Once the pressure releases, open the lid and give a gentle stir. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves. Serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Butternut Squash With Red Lentils and Tamarind
description: Elevate your dinner with this delightful fusion of flavors! Tender butternut squash and hearty red lentils simmered in a savory blend of onions, garlic, and tomatoes, enriched with aromatic spices like turmeric, cumin, and coriander. The tangy tamarind paste adds a unique twist, balancing the sweetness of the squash and earthiness of the lentils. Garnish with fresh cilantro for a vibrant finish. Perfect served over rice or with warm naan bread, this recipe promises a satisfying and nutritious meal in every bite.
ingredients: 1 butternut squash, peeled, seeded, and diced , 1 cup red lentils, rinsed , 1 onion, finely chopped , 3 cloves garlic, minced , 1 tablespoon grated ginger , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 2 tablespoons tamarind paste , 1 teaspoon ground turmeric , 1 teaspoon ground cumin , 1 teaspoon ground coriander , 1/2 teaspoon chili powder (adjust to taste) , Salt to taste , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish , Cooked rice or naan bread for serving.
instruction: Heat some oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until translucent. Add the minced garlic and grated ginger to the pot. Cook for another minute until fragrant. Stir in the diced butternut squash and cook for about 5 minutes until slightly softened. Add the chopped tomatoes, red lentils, tamarind paste, ground turmeric, ground cumin, ground coriander, chili powder, and salt to the pot. Mix well to combine. Pour enough water into the pot to cover all the ingredients. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for about 20-25 minutes until the lentils and squash are tender. Once cooked, taste and adjust the seasoning if needed. Serve the Butternut Squash With Red Lentils and Tamarind hot, garnished with fresh cilantro leaves, and accompanied by cooked rice or naan bread.

name: Creamy Mushroom and Green Bean Masala
description: Creamy Mushroom and Green Bean Masala blends tender mushrooms and crisp green beans with a rich, aromatic sauce. This vegetarian delight combines the earthy flavor of mushrooms with the freshness of green beans, creating a harmonious and satisfying dish. The creamy texture of the sauce, enriched with yogurt and heavy cream, perfectly complements the vibrant spices, resulting in a comforting and flavorful meal. Serve this masala hot with rice or naan for a wholesome and delicious dining experience.
ingredients: 250g mushrooms, sliced , 200g green beans, trimmed and halved , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch piece of ginger, grated , 1 green chili, finely chopped (optional) , 1/2 cup plain yogurt , 1/2 cup heavy cream , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon ground coriander , 1 teaspoon ground turmeric , 1 teaspoon garam masala , 1/2 teaspoon red chili powder , Salt to taste , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish , 2 tablespoons cooking oil.
instruction: Heat oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn translucent. Add minced garlic, grated ginger, and green chili (if using). Sauté for another minute. Add sliced mushrooms and green beans to the pan. Cook for about 5-7 minutes until they are tender. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften and release their juices. Stir in ground coriander, turmeric, garam masala, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well to coat the vegetables evenly with the spices. Lower the heat and add plain yogurt and heavy cream to the pan. Stir gently to combine all the ingredients. Let the masala simmer for 5-7 minutes until it thickens slightly and the flavors meld together. Taste and adjust seasoning if needed. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves before serving. Serve hot with steamed rice or naan bread.

name: Jackfruit Curry
description: A delectable fusion of flavors, Jackfruit Curry offers a delightful culinary experience. Tender jackfruit pieces are simmered in a fragrant blend of spices, including turmeric, cumin, coriander, and garam masala, creating a rich and aromatic curry. Enhanced with creamy coconut milk, this dish boasts a perfect balance of sweetness and spice. Garnished with fresh cilantro leaves, it pairs wonderfully with steamed rice or warm bread. This vegetarian delight promises to tantalize taste buds with every savory bite.
ingredients: 1 ripe jackfruit, seeds removed and cut into bite-sized pieces , 2 tablespoons oil (coconut oil or vegetable oil) , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch piece of ginger, grated , 2 green chilies, chopped (adjust according to spice preference) , 1 teaspoon ground turmeric , 1 teaspoon ground cumin , 1 teaspoon ground coriander , 1 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , 1 cup coconut milk , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish.
instruction: Heat the oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until it becomes translucent. Add the minced garlic, grated ginger, and chopped green chilies to the pan. Sauté for another 2-3 minutes until fragrant. Stir in the ground turmeric, ground cumin, ground coriander, garam masala, and salt. Mix well to combine the spices with the onion mixture. Add the jackfruit pieces to the pan and stir until they are coated with the spice mixture. Pour in the coconut milk and bring the curry to a simmer. Cover the pan and let it cook for about 20-25 minutes, or until the jackfruit is tender. Once the jackfruit is cooked through and the curry has thickened, remove the pan from heat. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves before serving. Serve hot with steamed rice or your favorite bread.

name: Sour Cream Thepla
description: Elevate your breakfast or snack time with these delectable Sour Cream Theplas! Bursting with flavor and aroma, these savory flatbreads are made with a blend of whole wheat flour, tangy sour cream, and aromatic spices. The addition of fresh coriander leaves and zesty ginger adds a delightful kick to every bite. Enjoy these soft and slightly crispy theplas with a dollop of yogurt or your favorite chutney for a truly satisfying culinary experience. Perfect for any occasion, these Sour Cream Theplas are sure to become a family favorite!
ingredients: 1 cup whole wheat flour , 1/4 cup sour cream , 1/4 cup chopped fresh coriander leaves , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon grated ginger , 1 green chili, finely chopped , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon cumin powder , 1/2 teaspoon coriander powder , Salt to taste , Oil for cooking.
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour, sour cream, chopped coriander leaves, grated ginger, chopped green chili, turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well. Gradually add water as needed to knead the mixture into a smooth dough. The dough should be soft and pliable. Divide the dough into 6 equal-sized portions and roll each portion into a ball. Take one portion of the dough and flatten it slightly between your palms. Dust the flattened dough with some flour and roll it out into a thin circle using a rolling pin. Heat a tawa or skillet over medium heat and place the rolled-out thepla on it. Cook the thepla for about 1-2 minutes on one side until small bubbles start to appear. Flip the thepla and cook the other side for another 1-2 minutes until light golden brown spots appear. Apply a little oil on both sides of the thepla and cook for another 1-2 minutes until evenly cooked and crisp. Remove the cooked thepla from the tawa and repeat the process with the remaining dough portions. Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or any chutney of your choice.

name: Vegan Sunflower Saag With Black-Eyed Peas
description: Vegan Sunflower Saag With Black-Eyed Peas combines the earthy flavors of black-eyed peas with the creamy richness of sunflower seeds, creating a hearty and nutritious dish perfect for any meal. This vegan recipe features a blend of spinach and optional fenugreek leaves cooked with onions, tomatoes, and a fragrant mix of spices. The addition of sunflower seed paste adds a unique twist to the traditional saag, elevating its texture and taste. Served with rice or bread, this wholesome dish offers a delightful culinary experience that's both satisfying and packed with plant-based goodness.
ingredients: 1 cup dried black-eyed peas, soaked overnight , 2 cups fresh spinach leaves, washed and chopped , 1 cup fresh fenugreek leaves (methi), washed and chopped (optional) , 1/2 cup sunflower seeds , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, chopped , 3 cloves garlic, minced , 1-inch piece ginger, grated , 2 green chilies, chopped (adjust to taste) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 teaspoon ground coriander , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala , Salt to taste , 2 tablespoons cooking oil , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish.
instruction: Drain and rinse the soaked black-eyed peas. In a large pot, add the black-eyed peas and enough water to cover them. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer until the peas are tender, about 30-40 minutes. Drain and set aside. In a blender or food processor, blend the sunflower seeds with a little water to make a smooth paste. Set aside. In a large skillet or pan, heat the cooking oil over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Stir in the minced garlic, grated ginger, and chopped green chilies. Sauté for another minute. Add the chopped tomatoes and cook until they are soft and mushy. Add the chopped spinach and fenugreek leaves (if using) to the skillet. Cook until the leaves wilt and reduce in volume. Stir in the cooked black-eyed peas and the sunflower seed paste. Mix well to combine. Add the ground coriander, turmeric powder, garam masala, and salt to taste. Stir to combine all the ingredients evenly. Cook the mixture for another 5-7 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld together and the sauce to thicken slightly. Once cooked, garnish with fresh cilantro leaves and serve hot with rice or bread of your choice.

name: Instant Pot Konkani Lobia
description: This traditional Konkani dish features tender black-eyed peas cooked to perfection in aromatic spices. Prepared effortlessly in the Instant Pot, this flavorful recipe combines mustard seeds, cumin, and a blend of spices for a delightful culinary experience. Enjoy this hearty and nutritious dish as a comforting meal with rice or roti, perfect for a wholesome family dinner or a casual gathering with friends.
ingredients: 1 cup dried black-eyed peas (lobia) , 2 tablespoons oil , 1 teaspoon mustard seeds , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 medium onion, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 tomato, chopped , 1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , Salt to taste , 2 cups water , Fresh coriander leaves for garnish.
instruction: Rinse the black-eyed peas (lobia) under cold water and soak them in water for at least 4 hours or overnight. Drain before using. Turn on the Instant Pot and select the "Sauté" mode. Heat oil in the pot. Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds. Let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown. Add green chilies and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté for another minute. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn mushy. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well. Add soaked black-eyed peas (lobia) and water. Stir to combine. Close the Instant Pot with the lid and set the vent to sealing position. Cook on high pressure for 10 minutes. Once the cooking cycle is complete, allow natural pressure release for 10 minutes, then carefully release the remaining pressure manually. Open the lid and garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or roti.

name: Til Wale Aloo
description: Til Wale Aloo is a delightful Indian dish where diced potatoes are cooked until golden brown and crispy, then tossed with aromatic spices and toasted sesame seeds. This flavorful combination creates a satisfying and comforting side dish that pairs perfectly with roti, paratha, or rice. With its simple yet enticing flavors, Til Wale Aloo is sure to become a favorite on your dining table.
ingredients: 4 medium-sized potatoes, peeled and diced , 2 tablespoons sesame seeds (til) , 2 tablespoons oil (vegetable or mustard oil) , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds (jeera) , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder (haldi) , 1 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste) , Salt to taste , Fresh cilantro leaves for garnish (optional).
instruction: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add diced potatoes to the pan and stir well. Cook the potatoes for about 10 minutes or until they turn golden brown, stirring occasionally. In the meantime, dry roast the sesame seeds in a separate pan until they turn golden brown and fragrant. Keep aside. Once the potatoes are cooked, add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well to coat the potatoes evenly with the spices. Cook for another 5-7 minutes or until the potatoes are fully cooked and crispy on the outside. Finally, add the roasted sesame seeds to the potatoes and mix gently. Garnish with fresh cilantro leaves if desired. Serve hot as a side dish with roti, paratha, or rice.

name: Masala Urad Dal
description: This flavorful Masala Urad Dal combines soaked black gram lentils with a medley of aromatic spices, creating a hearty and satisfying dish. Sautéed onions, tomatoes, and ginger-garlic paste lend a rich depth of flavor, while spices like turmeric, red chili, and garam masala add warmth and complexity. Garnished with fresh coriander leaves, this dish pairs perfectly with rice or roti for a comforting and nutritious meal.
ingredients: 1 cup whole urad dal (black gram lentils), rinsed and soaked for 4-6 hours , 2 tablespoons ghee or vegetable oil , 1 teaspoon cumin seeds , 1 onion, finely chopped , 2 tomatoes, finely chopped , 2 green chilies, slit lengthwise , 1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste , 1 teaspoon turmeric powder , 1 teaspoon red chili powder , 1 teaspoon coriander powder , 1/2 teaspoon garam masala powder , Salt to taste , Chopped coriander leaves for garnishing , Lemon wedges for serving (optional).
instruction: Drain the soaked urad dal and rinse it again. In a pressure cooker, add the rinsed urad dal along with 3 cups of water. Pressure cook for 3-4 whistles or until the dal is soft and cooked through. Once done, set aside. Heat ghee or vegetable oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and slit green chilies. Sauté for a minute until the raw smell disappears. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn mushy and the oil starts to separate. Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and garam masala powder. Mix well and cook for another 2-3 minutes. Add the cooked urad dal along with its water to the pan. Stir well and let it simmer for 5-10 minutes until the flavors are well combined. Adjust the consistency by adding more water if needed. Add salt to taste and mix well. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or roti. You can also squeeze some lemon juice on top before serving for extra tanginess (optional).

name: Bombay Masala Chile Cheese Toasties
description: Bombay Masala Chile Cheese Toasties are a delightful fusion of flavors, bringing together the zing of green chilies, the warmth of spices, and the gooey richness of cheese. These toasties feature a filling made with mashed potatoes, finely chopped onions, green chilies, and a blend of aromatic spices like chaat masala, cumin, and coriander. Generously stuffed between slices of bread and grilled to perfection with a golden-brown crust, these toasties are crispy on the outside and irresistibly cheesy on the inside. Perfect for a quick snack or a light meal, these Bombay Masala Chile Cheese Toasties are sure to tantalize your taste buds with every bite.
ingredients: 8 slices of bread (white or whole wheat) , 1 large potato, boiled and mashed , 1 small onion, finely chopped , 1 green chili, finely chopped (adjust according to taste) , 1/2 cup grated cheese (cheddar or mozzarella) , 1 teaspoon chaat masala , 1/2 teaspoon ground cumin , 1/2 teaspoon ground coriander , Salt to taste , Butter or ghee for spreading.
instruction: In a mixing bowl, combine the mashed potato, chopped onion, green chili, grated cheese, chaat masala, ground cumin, ground coriander, and salt. Mix well until all ingredients are evenly incorporated. Take a slice of bread and spread a generous amount of the potato-cheese mixture evenly over it. Place another slice of bread on top to form a sandwich. Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat. Spread a little butter or ghee on both sides of the sandwich. Place the sandwich on the pan and cook until the bottom side is golden brown and crispy, then flip and cook the other side until golden brown and crispy as well. Repeat with the remaining sandwiches. Once all sandwiches are cooked, remove them from the pan and let them cool slightly before slicing them diagonally into triangles. Serve the Bombay Masala Chile Cheese Toasties hot with your favorite chutney or sauce.

name: Chile-Garlic Kulcha
description: Elevate your culinary experience with our tantalizing Chile-Garlic Kulcha recipe. Bursting with bold flavors of minced garlic, fiery green chilies, and aromatic cilantro, each bite of these stuffed Indian flatbreads promises a delightful fusion of spice and zest. Simple to prepare and utterly irresistible, our Chile-Garlic Kulchas make for a perfect accompaniment to your favorite curries or chutneys. Try them today and embark on a flavorful journey that will leave your taste buds craving for more.
ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour , 1/2 cup plain yogurt , 1 teaspoon baking powder , 1 teaspoon sugar , 1/2 teaspoon salt , 2 tablespoons olive oil , 4 cloves garlic, minced , 2 green chilies, finely chopped , 2 tablespoons fresh cilantro, chopped , Butter for brushing.
instruction: In a large mixing bowl, combine the all-purpose flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt. Add the plain yogurt and olive oil to the flour mixture. Mix well to form a dough. Knead the dough on a lightly floured surface for about 5 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 10 minutes. Meanwhile, prepare the filling by mixing the minced garlic, chopped green chilies, and fresh cilantro in a small bowl. Divide the dough into 8 equal-sized portions. Roll each portion into a ball and flatten it slightly with your hands. Place a spoonful of the garlic-chili-cilantro filling in the center of each flattened dough portion. Fold the edges of the dough over the filling and pinch to seal, forming a stuffed ball. Roll out each stuffed ball into a flatbread (kulcha) using a rolling pin. The kulchas should be about 1/4 inch thick. Heat a skillet or tawa over medium heat. Place a rolled kulcha on the skillet and cook for 2-3 minutes on each side until golden brown spots appear. Brush the cooked kulchas with butter while still warm. Repeat the process with the remaining dough portions to make more kulchas. Serve the Chile-Garlic Kulchas hot with your favorite curry or chutney.

name: Ros Omelette
description: A delightful fusion of eggs and aromatic spices, the Ros Omelette is a beloved dish cherished for its simplicity and flavor. With ingredients like onions, tomatoes, and green chilies, each bite offers a burst of freshness and warmth. Easy to prepare and versatile in its serving options, this dish makes for a satisfying breakfast or a quick meal any time of the day. Whether paired with toast or enjoyed on its own, the Ros Omelette is sure to tantalize your taste buds with its savory goodness.
